INVESTMENT PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Islamic Republic of Pakistan 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Energy 
Subsector: Transmission and distribution 
Themes: Sustainable economic growth, capacity development 
Subthemes:  Fostering  physical  infrastructure  development, 
institutional development 
   
Environment  Tranche 1 – Category B (three subprojects category B, sixteen 
Assessment  category C). 
   
Sector Investment  The Medium-Term Development Framework, 2005–2010 (MTDF), 
Program Description  prepared by the Government of Pakistan in May 2005, established 
  a  framework  for  the  power  sector  development.  The  MTDF 
  envisages  additional  power  generation,  transmission,  and 
  distribution  capacities  in  order  to  ensure  sufficient  electricity 
  supply to meet the projected 8% per annum growth in demand 
  over the planning period. The growth in demand was about 12% 
  in FY2006.  
   
  Power  generation  is  expected  to  grow  from  about  19,540 
  megawatts (MW) in 2005 to 162,590 MW in 2030. The bulk of the 
  additional supply is expected to be met through an expansion of 
  domestic and imported thermal and hydropower generation. The 
  Government  is  currently  pursuing  a  combination  of  public  and 
  private  options  to  ensure  new  generation  can  be  added  as 
  required. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is actively working 
  with the Government and private power generation developers to 
  finance public- and privately-owned generation stations to meet 
  the current and future demand for electricity. 
   
  This Investment Program focuses on power transmission. In order 
  to  facilitate  efficient  and  effective  evacuation  of  power  from 
  existing power stations, the National Transmission and Despatch 
  Company (NTDC), in coordination with the Ministry of Water and 
  Power (MOWP), has prepared a Transmission Sector Road Map, 
  2007–2017. The road map addresses the current shortcomings of 
  the power transmission system by recommending rehabilitation, 
  augmentation, and expansion projects and power evacuation from 
  the planned power stations in the least-cost power generation 
  plan. The total cost of the NTDC investment plan is estimated at 
  $3.9 billion. It is envisaged that ADB will finance $800 million 
  (20%) of the total investment plan. 
   
  NTDC was established as part of the unbundling of the Water and 
  Power  Development  Authority  (WAPDA)  in  1998  to  operate, 
  manage, and develop the national power transmission network. 
  The  immediate  concern  of  NTDC  is  the  capacity  of  the

ii   
  transmission  network  to  evacuate  and  transmit  the  generated 
  power to load centers. The 13,051 MW peak demand recorded in 
  2006 was constrained by the transmission system and there was 
an estimated 800 MW of unsatisfied demand. As a result, some 
transmission  sections  operated  at  or  above  rating  limits, 
increasing  the  risk  of  transmission  failure  and  costly  service 
restoration. The inability to transmit all of the available generated 
power has the same effect as a generation shortage and results in 
load shedding to prevent system failure and collapse.  
 
The 500 kilovolt (kV) system provides the main power flow route 
between the north and the south of Pakistan.  The bulk of the 
power  is  generated  in  the  north  (hydropower)  and  the  south 
(thermal power) with the major load centers being in the middle of 
the  country  around  Lahore,  Faisalabad,  and  Islamabad.  As  a 
result there are always significant power flows from the north or 
the  south  to  the  centre,  depending  on  the  season  and  the 
availability of hydropower.  At the end of FY2006, 77% of the 500 
kV and 69% of the 220 kV power transformers were overloaded.  
This means that security of supply standards cannot be met and 
NTDC  cannot  meet  its  transmission  license  obligations.  The 
expertise  of  NTDC  operating  staff  has  prevented  the  situation 
from becoming worse, but there are limits to what can be done 
with the system under current stress. 
 
Additionally, the key load centers run at a very low power factor 
and this, combined with long transmission lines, places a very 
high  reactive  power  requirement  on  the  power  transmission 
system. The reactive power results in a high current flow, which 
does not contribute to efficient power transmission, reduces the 
effective  transfer  capacity  of  the  system,  and/or  causes 
transmission system voltages to fall below acceptable limits.  
 
There are plans to increase power generation, but development of 
the  transmission  system  has,  to  date,  not  received  sufficient 
attention.  The planned increase in power generation will strain 
the transmission system still further, and the full benefits of the 
extra  power  generation  will  not  be  achieved  without  urgent 
investments in the transmission system.  
 
Planning and project development capacity is essential for timely 
transmission  investments  since  transmission  system 
reinforcement both lags behind and has a longer lead time than 
new  generation  (e.g.,  gas-fired  generation  plants  can  be 
operational within 2 years of initiation). This further emphasizes 
the  importance  of  advance  planning  and  accelerating  the 
transmission system reinforcement process. 
 
Tranche 1 under the Investment Program will have 19 subprojects 
to augment, rehabilitate, and expand the transmission system. 
The subprojects will provide 26 transformers, 2 new substations,

iii
50 km of transmission line and 1 static var compensator. 
 
A  support  component  is  an  integral  part  of  the  proposed 
Investment  Program.  This  component  will  strengthen  NTDC’s 
project (i) planning, (ii) design, (iii) implementation, (iv) operations, 
and (v) monitoring capabilities. The total cost of the Investment 
Program support component is estimated at $10 million for the 
duration  of  the  Investment  Program.  The  objective  of  the 
component is to provide both resources and capacity to enable 
NTDC  to  improve  and  expand  its  current  project  preparation, 
implementation,  and  monitoring  capabilities.  Three  streams  of 
activities will be developed to cover: (i) power transmission project 
implementation, including general business management, portfolio 
review,  project  management,  and  program  management; 
(ii) technical operation and maintenance; (iii) accounting, financial 
and economic management, financial reporting; (iv) contracting, 
procurement  and  inventory  management;  (v)  a  management 
information  system  and  economics  of  cost  recovery  and  tariff 
setting;  and  (vi)  project  development,  including  policy 
development,  a  feasibility  study,  site  identification,  and  project 
design. 
 
The Government has completed the legal unbundling of NTDC 
from  WAPDA,  and  the  National  Electric  Power  Regulatory 
Authority (NEPRA) has determined a transmission tariff which is 
sufficient to sustain NTDC operations. During the implementation 
of the Investment Program, further improvements and refinements 
will be encouraged, and measures will be put in place to minimize 
the risk of regression. Timely submissions of tariff applications will 
be  ensured  and  NTDC’s  financial  and  operational  autonomy 
safeguarded. 
 
Multitranche Financing  The Government has requested ADB to provide financing through 
Facility  a multitranche financing facility (MFF) for $800 million over 10 
  years,  which  represents  20%  of  the  total  investment  plan  for 
  2007–2016 of $3.9 billion. The MFF has a maximum utilization 
period of 10 years, and the periodic finance requests (PFRs) will 
be converted into separate loans. 
 
The  Government  has  entered  into  a  framework  financing 
agreement  (FFA)  with  ADB  for  up  to  $800  million  through 
individual  loans.  The  draft  FFA  satisfies  the  requirements  of 
ADB’s Pilot Financing Instruments and Modalities document.  
 
In accordance with the FFA, the Government has submitted the 
first  PFR  to  ADB  in  an  amount  of  $226  million  from  ordinary 
capital  resources  (OCR)  and  in  an  amount  of  $10  million 
equivalent  in  SDRs  from  Asian  Development  Fund  (ADF) 
resources. The first PFR for these two loans will be presented to 
ADB’s Board of Directors at the same time as this paper and the 
FFA.

iv   
 
Rationale  Power is an essential commodity for growth and expansion and in 
turn  for  the  economic  and  social  development  of  Pakistan. 
Historically, power generation has received much more attention 
than  transmission.  This  Investment  Program  seeks  to 
(i) rehabilitate, augment, and expand parts of the system to meet 
current generation capacities; (ii) expand and augment the system 
to cope with future power generation stations; and (iii) ensure 
continued  operation  and  maintenance  in  accordance  with  best 
international practices.  
 
The  Government  is  committed  to  developing  the  power 
transmission system to ensure an adequate and reliable supply of 
electricity.  
   
Impact and Outcome  The Investment Program will finance investments that will support 
social  and  economic  prosperity  and  growth.  The  inadequate 
supply of electricity has become a bottleneck inhibiting economic 
growth and affecting all consumer groups and social classes. The 
Investment Program will address this bottleneck, improve future 
performance, and increase efficiency and effectiveness through 
technical and other improvements. 
 
The  Investment  Program  will  improve  energy  efficiency  and 
provide institutional capacity for (i) implementation and monitoring 
support, and (ii) project preparatory activities for the Investment 
Program’s subprojects and other NTDC undertakings.   
   
NTDC’s Investment Plan   The total investment cost of NTDC’s investment plan for 2007–
2016 is estimated at $3.9 billion.

v
 
Multitranche Financing  The  maximum  financing  amount  available  under  the  MFF  is 
Facility Amount and  $800,000,000. The MFF comprises $790,000,000 from ordinary 
Terms  capital  resources  (OCR)  and  $10,000,000  equivalent  in  SDRs 
  from  ADF  resources.  The  MFF  is  designed  to  finance  part  of 
  NTDC’s investment plan, through individual loans. 
   
  Financing from OCR resources will be subject to interest to be 
  determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered 
  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility.  Each  loan  will  have  a 
  repayment period of 20 years, including a grace period of 3 years, 
  and an interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-
  based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.75%, a front-end 
  fee of 1.0% is waived for all public sector loans approved from 1 
  July  2006  to  30  June  2006,  conversion  options  that  may  be 
  exercised  in  accordance  with  the  terms  of  the  FFA,  the  loan 
  regulations, and such other terms set forth in the draft Loan and 
  Project Agreements. Financing from ADF resources equivalent in 
  special drawings rights to $10 million will have an interest charge 
  at the rate of 1% per annum during the grace period, and 1.5% 
  per  annum  thereafter,  and  a  repayment  period  of  32  years, 
  including a grace period of 8 years.  
   
  The Government shall make the proceeds of the loans available 
  to NTDC upon terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB.  
Disbursement   
The individual loan proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with 
ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook and Interim Guidelines for 
Disbursement Operations, LIBOR-Based Loan Products, both as 
amended from time to time.  
   
Allocation and Relending  Relending  from  the  Government  to  NTDC  will  be  in  Pakistan 
Terms  rupees at an interest rate and terms and conditions satisfactory to 
ADB. The foreign exchange risk will be borne by the Government. 
ADB  teams  will  conduct  due  diligence  on  the  subprojects 
mentioned in the PFRs, to ensure that they comply with the FFA. 
   
Advance Contracting  For  each  subproject  and  for  the  support  component,  advance 
and Retroactive  contracting  for  procurement  of  equipment,  civil  works,  and 
Financing  consulting services will be allowed, subject to these being eligible 
  according  to  agreed  procedures,  and  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. 
 
Retroactive financing may be available under individual loans for 
expenditures  incurred  12  months  prior  to  the  signing  of  the 
corresponding Loan Agreement, with a ceiling of up to 20% for the 
loan amount, according to the paper Cost Sharing and Eligibility of 
Expenditures  for  Asian  Development  Bank  Financing:  A  New 
Approach. The Government and NTDC have been informed that 
approval of advance contracting and retroactive financing does 
not commit ADB to financing any of the proposed subprojects.

vi   
 
Period of Utilization  The utilization period will be for 10 years from 2007 to 2016, with 
the last PFR to be submitted by the end of 2014. Each specific 
loan will have its own closing date to match its implementation 
period. 
   
Estimated Investment  The estimated project completion date is 31 December 2016. 
Program Completion 
Date 
   
Implementation  NTDC will be responsible for the implementation of the Investment 
Arrangements  Program and its individual projects as per the Project Agreements. 
   
Executing Agency  The National Transmission and Despatch Company Ltd. will be 
the Executing Agency. 
   
Procurement  Procurement to be financed under the Investment Program will be 
done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2006). 
International competitive bidding (ICB) will be used for goods and 
works funded under the Investment Program. ICB will be utilized 
for supply contracts estimated to cost the equivalent of or more 
than $1 million. ICB will be used for works contracts estimated to 
cost the equivalent of or more than $5 million. A procurement plan 
has  been  prepared  to  ensure  maximum  competition  under 
international competitive bidding.   
   
Consulting Services  Consulting  services  will  be  required  for,  among  others, 
(i) preparation  of  subprojects,  (ii)  detailed  design,  and 
(iii) construction  supervision  and  contract  management. 
Consultants  will  be  selected  and  engaged  in  accordance  with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2006). Consulting 
firms will be selected through international competition using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method. Individual consultants 
may be recruited for specific assignments in accordance with the 
ADB’s  procedure.  It  is  envisioned  that,  because  of  the 
continuation of a number of tasks during implementation, single-
source selection may be used for certain assignments with the 
prior approval of ADB. 
   
Investment Program  The Investment Program is designed to provide all grid-connected 
Benefits and  consumers with an adequate and reliable supply of electricity, 
Beneficiaries  which would support the Government’s MTDF objective of 8% 
GDP growth per annum. Substantial investments to rehabilitate, 
augment, and expand the power transmission system will result in 
more reliable supply to the residential, agricultural, commercial, 
and industrial consumers within Pakistan. Schools, hospitals, and 
other social services will be among the beneficiaries.  
 
By  ensuring  sufficient  investment  in  the  power  transmission 
system, the Government will be able to encourage the private 
sector  to  invest  in  power  generation  stations  and  power

vii
distribution entities. A strong transmission backbone will alleviate 
concerns about evacuation of electricity and the ability to receive 
uninterrupted  supply.  An  envisaged  increase  in  private  sector 
involvement in the overall power sector will be a major benefit of 
the Investment Program.    
   
Risks and Assumptions  The  key  assumptions  underlying  the  Investment  Program  are 
(i) macroeconomic  growth  will  remain  stable;  (ii)  federal  and 
provincial  governments  will  remain  committed  to  power  sector 
reforms and there will be continued progress on policy, regulatory, 
and  institutional  reforms;  and  (iii)  counterpart  funds  will  be 
mobilized in a timely manner. 
 
Risks  to  the  Investment  Program  include:  (i)  delays  in  power 
sector reforms, both in tariff determinations and in notifications of 
the rates applicable to the distribution companies by NEPRA and 
the  Government;  (ii)  delays  in  tariff  determinations  and 
notifications of rates applicable to NTDC’s wheeling charges by 
NEPRA and the Government, to facilitate investments in power 
transmission facilities; (iii) an increase in prices of cement, steel, 
fuel, and other raw materials that would affect the financial viability 
of the Investment Program; (iv) delays in project implementation 
and  failure  to  secure  the  necessary  clearances  in  time  for 
construction; and (iv) failure to mobilize the necessary counterpart 
funds. These risks all appear to be low. NTDC is committed to 
expanding  power  supply  within  Pakistan  through  increased 
investment in the transmission facilities.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  for  the  Power 
Transmission Enhancement Investment Program. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Sector Overview 
2.  Pakistan’s power sector is faces tremendous challenges in its efforts to support the 
Government of Pakistan’s strategy of increasing the electricity supply to its urban and rural 
population  and  of  securing  overall  economic  growth.  The  key  challenges  are:  (i)  lack  of 
generation capacity, (ii) increasing constraints in the transmission and distribution systems, 
(iii) weak financial management and sustainability of the sector entities, and (iv) inadequate 
corporate governance structures for the successor companies. A detailed assessment of the 
power sector is provided in Appendix 2. 
 
3.  The power sector will need to increase its capacity to support the target of 8% annual 
growth  in  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  in  the  Government’s  Medium-Term  Development 
Framework, 2005–2010 (MTDF) and to meet the demand for and consumption of electricity 
such growth would imply. In addition, about 45% of Pakistan’s population has no access to 
electricity from the national grid and the Government is implementing an ambitious plan to 
significantly extend coverage in rural areas. Bottlenecks in the power transmission network are 
expected to result in significant system capacity shortfalls and to restrict GDP growth by almost 
0.8% in FY2008. 
 
4.  The availability of power is currently insufficient to meet peak system demand or to 
provide an adequate level of spinning reserve. Moreover, existing transmission constraints 
mean that the peak generation output cannot be delivered to distant load centers. If recent 
increases in demand continue, power shortages and customer disconnections will become 
much more common unless power transmission is significantly improved as a matter of urgency. 
 
5.  According to the Government’s power system estimates, at least 8% annual growth in 
electricity demand in Pakistan is forecast during 2005–2015. Pakistan will require an additional 
2,000 megawatts (MW) of power annually to meet this demand and this additional power will 
need to be evacuated through the transmission system. Substantial investments are required to 
strengthen the system to (i) urgently address current shortfalls, (ii) evacuate power generated 
by additional power plants, and (iii) supply electricity to meet the growing demand.  
 
6.  The currently installed generation capacity in Pakistan is 19,540 MW, of which 17,405 
MW is in the regions covered by Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA). However, 
the available generation capacity in the WAPDA regions is only about 13,000 MW because: 
(i) hydropower plants are dependent upon reservoir capacity and hence are affected by rainfall, 
reservoir  silting,  and  irrigation,  (ii)  the  generation  portfolio  is  ageing  and  subject  to  rating 
limitations  and  increased  maintenance  requirements,  and  (iii)  the  plants  are  increasingly 
unreliable.

2 
2.  Sector Policy and Strategy 
7.  In  2000,  the  Government  unveiled  a  “Vision  2025  Program”,  which  advocated 
accelerated development of new generation facilities. The power policy statement of 2000 was 
subsequently revised in 2002 and greater reliance was placed on indigenous fuel sources 
(hydropower  and  thermal  generation)  using  local  coal  or  gas  supplies,  and  renewable 
technologies. This power policy embodies the current policy for increasing the country’s power 
generation  capacity  and  encompasses  private,  public  and  private–public  models  of  project 
implementation. The MTDF envisages an ambitious investment program for the power sector in 
order to achieve a consistent 8% annual growth in GDP.   
 
8.  To  support  development  of  the  power  sector  and  to  encourage  private  sector 
participation, the Government has approved power sector policies, strategies, and action plans 
to (i) ensure independent regulation of the power sector; (ii) complete the unbundling of WAPDA 
by establishing four generation and eight distribution companies, and the National Transmission 
and  Despatch  Company  (NTDC);  (iii)  begin  the  power  sector  privatization  program;  and 
(iv) evaluate and optimize the fuel sources of the power sector to ensure energy security and 
minimize overall tariff requirements.  
 
9.  Implementation  of  the  Government’s  power  sector  strategy  would  have  three  main 
outcomes: (i) sector reforms to increase efficiencies and effectiveness and to create an enabling 
environment for more private sector participation and investment, (ii) capacity building in all 
sector  organizations,  covering  financial  management,  efficiency  improvement,  the  clean 
development mechanism, and project management; and (iii) completion of large infrastructure 
development projects in generation, transmission, and distribution. 
 
3.  Performance of the Power Transmission Sector  
10.  Transmission and distribution losses in the Pakistan power system amounted to 25% in 
2005. In the transmission system, these high losses are caused by the excess load on the 
transmission  lines  and  at  substations.  Total  transmission  losses  are  7.5%,  including  the 
secondary transmission system losses. The primary system losses are more than 3.0%. The 
primary transmission network consists of 4,377 circuit kilometers (km) of 500 kilovolt (kV) lines 
and 6,992 circuit km of 220 kV lines, with nine 500 or 220 kV substations, and 27 substations 
transforming 220 kV to lower voltages.  
 
11.  The 500 kV system provides the main power flow route between the north and the south 
of Pakistan. The bulk of the generation capacity is connected in the north (hydropower) and the 
south (thermal), with the major load center being in the middle of the country, centered around 
Faisalabad,  Islamabad,  and  Lahore.  As  a  result  there  are  always  significant  power  flow 
requirements from the north and the south to the center, depending on the seasonal availability 
of hydropower. 
 
12.  NTDC is the sole transmission company in Pakistan and is licensed to operate the 
primary transmission system (220 kV and above) and to dispatch all power generation linked to 
the national grid. Its transmission system links all major generating stations with the main load 
centers at the 500 kV and 220 kV level. Power is then disbursed through an extensive network 
of 220, 132, and 66 kV lines to the populated areas of the country. The 500 kV system forms a 
central spine running over a considerable distance from Tarbella and Peshawar in the north to 
Jamshoro and Karachi in the south.

3 
4.  National Transmission and Despatch Company (NTDC) 
13.  As the sole transmission company in Pakistan, NTDC is required to (i) maintain and 
upgrade the current system; (ii) plan, design, and implement system expansion; and (iii) operate 
the system dispatch generation according to system requirements and transmission license 
conditions  to  ensure  the  smooth  transmission  of  electricity  from  generation  companies  to 
distribution companies across the country. The company took over properties, rights, assets 
obligations and liabilities of 220 kV and 500 kV grid stations and the transmission lines and 
network owned by WAPDA under a business transfer agreement on 1 March 1999.  
 
14.  In terms of human resources, the transition of staff from WAPDA to NTDC has been 
completed.  The  transfer  of  assets  and  liabilities  has  also  been  substantially  completed. 
Independent  financial  statements  have  been  prepared  and  audited,  as  per  its  license,  for 
NTDC’s operations in FY 2004 and 2005. However, its financial independence has yet to reach 
the  level  required  of  an  autonomous  corporation.  WAPDA  currently  bills  and  collects  the 
transmission  wheeling  charges  from  distribution  companies. 1   Although  the  NEPRA’s 
determination of the transmission tariff and the Government’s notification of the tariff enable 
NTDC to charge distribution companies directly, it must make requests for funds to WAPDA for 
most of its payment needs. This prevents NTDC from achieving financial independence and 
adds procedures and inefficiency to NTDC’s and WAPDA’s financial operations.  
 
15.  External investment sources will be required to secure an efficient transmission system, 
especially for the costly evacuation from the new generation plants. Given the current financial 
arrangements,  it  will  be  difficult  to  attract  large  amounts  of  investment,  especially  from 
commercial sources, since NTDC does not control or have access to the cash flow from the 
distribution companies. NTDC should bill the distribution companies directly and collect charges 
from them. The separation of the billing for transmission and power will also prepare NTDC to 
collect revenues from bulk power consumers when they come into its jurisdiction. 
 
16.  The Government has determined that the single buyer function licensed to NTDC will be 
handled  by  an  independent  agency,  the  Central  Power  Purchasing  Agency  (CPPA).  The 
accumulated loss for the NTDC was PRs14 billion in FY2005 and there are overdue receivables 
from distribution companies. The financial burden on NTDC has been mainly due to its single 
buyer  function.  New  licenses  will  have  to  be  issued  to  NTDC  and  the  CPPA.  Tariff 
determinations  made  for  the  CPPA  and  agreements  with  generation  companies  and 
independent power plants (IPPs) have been revised, to reflect the CPPA as the single buyer. As 
an interim measure, the CPPA will be managed separately within NTDC. It will take on most of 
the  tasks  currently  being  performed  by  WAPDA’s  Private  Power  Organization.  Terms  of 
reference  for  the  management  of  the  independent  CPPA  have  been  drafted.  The  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  been  requested  to  provide  technical  assistance  for  the 
establishment of the CPPA. 
  
5.  NTDC Investment Plan  
17.  NTDC’s total investment requirement is estimated to be $3.9 billion in the period to 2016. 
The transmission investment plan covers 68 transformers, 4,415 km of lines, four static var 
compensators  (SVCs),  and  20  new  grid  stations.  The  urgent  and  immediate  transmission 
                                                 
1  NTDC receives payment directly from Karachi Electric Supply Company (KESC) for transmission services. Under 
current procedures, even this is transferred to WAPDA for disbursement upon the request of NTDC.

4 
system  rehabilitation  and  augmentation  plan  for  2007–2011  totals  $1.253  billion  (41 
transformers, 402 km of lines, and 4 SVCs). Investments for 2012–2016 will mainly facilitate the 
evacuation from new generation plants as per the least-cost power generation plan.  
 
18.  Subprojects commissioned from 2007 to 2011 will provide capacity to overloaded areas 
all over Pakistan.  By 2009, 19 subprojects will have been commissioned. 20 transformers will 
have been installed in existing substations, and six transformers will have been installed in two 
new substations.  The cost of the subprojects ranges from $4 million to $37 million. SVCs will be 
installed within the Lahore ring to improve electricity quality and stability. These investments are 
expected to add about 3,000 MW of capacity incrementally to the system by 2011. From 2009 to 
2011, subprojects will continue to augment the system though seven new substations, three 
SVCs, and 15 transformers.  By this time it is expected that the environmental and social work 
needed to enable the additional grid substations’ longer transmission lines (50–200 km) have 
been concluded, allowing a total of 352 km of transmission lines to be added to the network.   
 
19.  The timing of the subprojects to be commissioned from 2012 to 2016 depends largely on 
the completion date of the new generation plants. The new plants, such as the Basha dam 
dispersal, and the high voltage line linking Karachi and Lahore are due to be completed during 
this period. The cost estimates of the subprojects to be completed during this period range from 
$40 million to $1.2 billion.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Key Challenges of the Power Transmission Sector  
20.  Pakistan’s power transmission system faces three major challenges: (i) the heavy power 
flow through the 500 kV system, (ii) a shortage of supply capacity for the 220 kV system, and 
(iii) high transmission losses. The system is unable to meet the current peak demand, and is 
already falling behind the generation expansion targets. To enable the increased generating 
capacity to support the Government’s growth targets, the power transmission system must (i) be 
strengthened to meet current system requirements and fulfill peak demand, and (ii) keep pace 
with the commissioning of new generation plants.

5 
21.  The transmission system is aging, overloaded, and poorly maintained. It is unreliable, 
and  at  times  there  is  a  risk  of  collapse.  The  system  needs  immediate  rehabilitation, 
augmentation,  and  expansion  so  it  can  meet  consumer  demands  and  system  security 
requirements. Ensuring the safe and reliable transmission of electricity will be a major challenge 
for Pakistan.  
 
22.  The mismatch between the location of demand and the source of supply in the existing 
power system means that investments will have to be made in the primary network. Current 
peak energy and capacity shortfalls are to some extent the consequence of shortages and 
bottlenecks  in  the  national  network.  Primary  network  constraints  cause  inefficiencies  for 
consumers, such as high levels of un-served energy or investment in costly self- or captive 
generation, at a significant cost. Export competitiveness, for example, of the textile sector, is 
eroded by high electricity costs and unreliable power supplies. Meanwhile, demand growth is 
forecast to continue unabated.  
 
23.  The immediate concern is the capacity of the power transmission network to evacuate 
and transmit the present output to load centers. The record maximum transmission system 
demand in the summer of 2006 was 13,051 MW, representing the system at full capacity. It has 
been estimated at that time there was 800 MW of unsatisfied demand due to load shedding. 
Even  with  this  constrained  demand,  sections  of  the  transmission  network  are  running 
periodically  above  rating  limits,  thereby  increasing  further  the  risk  of  lengthy  transmission 
outages.  
 
24.  This load shedding figure does not include the load shed due to under-frequency and 
low voltage. The gap between generation supply and demand at present and in the near future 
indicates  that  the  primary  system  is  heavily  stressed  and  in  urgent  need  of  additional 
investment, even at current levels of demand. About 77% of 500 kV and 69% of 220 kV power 
transformers were overloaded in 2006. About 24% of 500 kV and 20% of 220 kV transformers 
were more than 80% overloaded. Further additions to the system are required in order to 
achieve the obligatory reliability standards and to improve the quality of supply significantly.  
 
25.  Although power generation plans are moving forward, development of the transmission 
system  has,  to  date,  not  received  sufficient attention.  The  planned  increase  in  generation 
capacity will further exacerbate the transmission constraints, and the full benefits of the extra 
generation will not be achieved unless there is urgent investment in the transmission system. 
 
26.  The Government is taking steps to address the situation and has approved a power 
transmission sector road map, a comprehensive government plan that specifies the details of 
system renovation and expansion. The objective of the road map is to show how a reliable and 
high-quality power supply can meet rising demand from industrial, commercial, agricultural, and 
domestic customers. The road map is consistent with the Government’s poverty reduction 
strategy  that  aims  to  increase  the  level  of  economic  activity  and  to  achieve  the  following 
outcomes: (i) a more efficient power system; (ii) high-quality power supply through a more 
reliable and stable system; (iii) greater geographic coverage of power supply; and (iv) greater 
access to affordable electricity, by bringing hydroelectric and coal-fired thermal energy to load 
centers. The NTDC investment plan for 2007–2016 is shown in Appendix 3. 
 
2.  Financial Issues  
27.  The financial health and sustainability of the power sector is dependent on timely and 
accurate (i) submission of tariff applications by the distribution companies; (ii) execution of the

6 
tariff determination by NEPRA; (iii) notification of the tariff determination by the Government; 
(iv) metering,  billing,  and  collection  by  the  distribution  companies;  (v)  payment  of  subsidy 
allocations  by  the  Government;  (vi)  payment  from  distribution  companies  to  NTDC  for 
transmission charges; and (vii) settlement of purchases and sale of electricity by the CPPA.  
 
28.  The unbundling of the power sector has been in progress since 1999. To achieve the 
efficiencies and transparency that were intended by the unbundling, financial and management 
independence  is  necessary.  Although  the  NTDC  continues  to  be  financially  dependent  on 
WAPDA,  it  has  satisfactory  accounting  systems  and  external  audit  processes  that  are  in 
accordance with international audit standards. It is developing in-house payment, billing, and 
collection systems. Accordingly, these functions can safely be transferred to NTDC. ADB is 
currently providing technical assistance 2 (TA) to strengthen NTDC capacities. As an immediate 
step, WAPDA is expected to provide monthly payments to NTDC for transmission charges.  
 
3.  Governance Matters 
29.  As the transition period is coming to an end and NTDC has built capacity to enable its 
independence from WAPDA, the corporate governance structure of its board needs to be in 
accordance with best international practice. Currently, the board consists of a chairman, three 
members from the private sector, and three officials representing the owner, the Government of 
Pakistan. The nomination of the board members is made by chairman of Pakistan Electric 
Power Company (PEPCO) in accordance with a presidential directive.  The chairman of NTDC 
and another director concurrently hold seats in WAPDA, PEPCO, and the NTDC. A situation 
where the same individual holds many positions on boards of directors is counterproductive to 
the Government’s power sector policy. When the NTDC becomes fully independent, there will 
be a conflict of interest if an NTDC board member also sits on the board of WAPDA or another 
company that holds generation assets. Such conflicts of interest would make it difficult for 
individuals to exercise their fiduciary duties and carry out their oversight role. 
 
4.  Private Sector Participation  
30.  The Government is acutely aware of the need for private sector participation in the 
sector. In 2002, it set out a policy for power generation projects, which provided a clear set of 
incentives,  along  with  a  regulatory  regime,  to  attract  private  capital.  Pakistan  has  been 
successful in attracting private sector investment and is working to further improve the enabling 
environment.3 The 15 commissioned IPPs make up about 4,000 MW of generating capacity.   
  
31.  In line with overall power sector policies, the power transmission subsectors promotes 
private sector economic activities by making available power through evacuation of electricity  
from  the IPPs, after approval of the IPPs by the Government has been obtained. A robust 
transmission system is the anchor for private sector investments in power generation facilities 
and power distribution companies. Through substantial investments in the transmission system, 
the Government will be able to establish an environment that is conducive to private sector

7 
investments. At the same time it will remove concerns about the ability to evacuate power from 
IPPs  and  ensure  a  continuous  supply  of  power  to  the  distribution  companies.  The  power 
transmission investment program and the policies of the Private Power and Infrastructure Board 
(PPIB) specify role of NTDC in public–private partnerships. These include (i) the design of 
power evacuation facilities from approved IPPs, (ii) a clear definition of power transmission 
financing mechanisms for IPPs, and (iii) an assurance that transmission lines for evacuation of 
electricity from IPPs will be built on time. Through this MFF, ADB will help the Government to 
promote public–private partnerships in the power sector, by (i) making further improvements to 
the  enabling  conditions  for  power  evacuation  using  public–private  partnerships,  and 
(ii) providing financial security for the funding of power transmission facilities dedicated to the 
evacuation of electricity from IPPs. 
 
32.  There  have  been  two  attempts  to  attract  private  sector  participation  in  the  power 
transmission subsector since the Government adopted its Transmission Line Policy in 1995.  
Although bidding for the projects was successful, neither attempt achieved financial closure.  
Taking the lessons learned from these projects, private sector participation will be actively 
sought for the larger subprojects. There is track record for transmission tariff determination and 
incentives given by government.  Some of the subprojects in the Investment Program are for 
evacuation of IPPs.   
 
5.  External Assistance 
33.  The major sources of external assistance to the power sector are ADB, the Government 
of Japan, and the World Bank. Together they provide more than half of the official external 
assistance. ADB has supported both Karachi Electric Supply Corporation (KESC) and the Water 
and  Power  Development  Authority  (WAPDA),  while  the  World  Bank  has  mainly  provided 
assistance to WAPDA. Pakistan’s development partners have been working together to evolve 
a strategy for the privatization of the power sector. ADB, the World Bank, and the Government 
have prepared a policy matrix, with a clear delineation of the division of labor between ADB and 
the World Bank.  
34.  Bilateral  Support.  The  Canadian  International  Development  Agency  (CIDA)  has 
supported WAPDA to rehabilitate the Warsak Hydroelectric Power Station. It has also provided 
assistance to strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Resources to 
develop and implement sound policies and regulatory frameworks to encourage private sector 
investment and to enforce effective conservation and environmental regulations. CIDA also 
supports public and private companies to develop and manage hydrocarbon resources. 
 
35.  The Government of Germany is supporting a hydropower promotion program and a grid 
station in Ghakkar for power transmission from Ghazi-Barotha. The Government of Japan is 
considering assistance for energy efficiency enhancement through improvements to the national 
grid, the load dispatch system, and area-specific electrification. 
 
36.  World Bank. The focus of the World Bank is on ensuring a competitive and efficient 
power sector that provides affordable electric power; increasing access to electricity in rural 
areas; putting in place efficient and competitive oil, gas and petroleum industries supported by 
effective  government  regulation;  and  increasing  exploration  of  mineral  resources  under  a 
modernized institutional, legal, and regulatory framework. It also carries out analytical work on 
governance and tariff issues, sector dialogue, subsidy policy for the oil and gas sectors, and 
policy dialogue on the mineral sector.

8 
37.  United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). UNDP provides assistance for an 
energy-efficiency project in the transport sector. It provides support for promoting renewable 
energy technologies and energy-efficient housing with a view to disseminating success stories 
in such areas as energy conservation and renewable technology, training of women in energy-
efficient use of home appliances, and liquefied petroleum gas promotion in the Northern Areas. 
 
6.  Lessons  
38.  Ten ADB-financed power projects approved before 1983 have been post-evaluated. All 
were  classified  as  generally  successful.  The  post-evaluation  findings  showed  an  average 
implementation delay of 2.4 years (78%). Five of the projects experienced an average cost 
overrun of about 82%, and the other five an under-run of 28%. The post-evaluations drew 
attention  to  the  need  for  an  in-depth  analysis  of  all  technical  issues  before  a  project  is 
formulated,  and  the  need  to  review  cost  estimates  comprehensively  at  appraisal.  The 
performance of ADB-financed projects after 1983 has improved. However, KESC and WAPDA 
have been unable to meet the system loss targets, and accordingly have not been able to 
comply with the financial covenants.  ADB loans are listed in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
39.  Tariff adjustments have been based on social equity and affordability considerations, 
which has led to a lack of commercial focus and inhibited KESC and WAPDA from generating 
enough funds to meet all expansion, rehabilitation, and reinforcement requirements. The utilities 
have lacked focused leadership, good management practices, and transparency in operational 
and  financial  matters.  Most  ADB-financed  projects  have  been  sector  loans.  This  allows 
considerable flexibility in selection of subprojects, and in the use of consultants for formulating 
the subprojects. As a result, cost overruns have been greatly reduced. However, slow project 
implementation  remains  a  problem.  Delays  have  been  caused  by  slow  procurement  of 
consultants and goods, bureaucratic procedures, organizational and institutional weaknesses, 
changes in project scope, and shortages of qualified staff.  
 
40.  Lessons learned from previous projects are reflected in three specific measures in the 
Investment  Program:  (i)  in-depth  preparation  of  the  subprojects  included  in  each  tranche, 
(ii) early action on procurement and consulting services, and (iii) measurable milestones and 
close implementation facilitation and supervision. To ensure quality at entry, each subproject 
has  been  evaluated  using  five  criteria:  (i)  technical;  (ii)  financial;  (iii) economic; 
(iv) environmental  assessment;  and  (v) social  assessment,  including  land  acquisition  and, 
where necessary, a resettlement plan. Such early attention to procurement will ensure that bid 
document preparation and review procedures do not lead to delays. Close follow-up during 
manufacturing  of  goods,  construction  of  civil  works,  and  installation  should  ensure  timely 
corrective measures where needed and an early completion of each subproject.     
 
7.  ADB Operations and Sector Strategy 
41.  ADB Operations. Since the start of ADB operations in Pakistan in 1968, total lending to 
the energy sector has amounted to about $3 billion, of which $2.4 billion has been to the power 
subsector and $0.6 billion to the natural gas and petroleum subsectors. During recent years, 
ADB’s overall lending to the energy sector has accounted for about 28% of its total lending to 
Pakistan. About 67% of the lending to the power subsector ($1.6 billion for 13 loans) has been 
provided  to  WAPDA  and  the  rest  to  KESC.  ADB  has  been  the  major  source  of  external 
assistance to the energy sector in Pakistan, having provided about one-third of total external 
resources. ADB’s nonlending activities in the sector have also been important, with a total of

9 
$14.2  million  provided  for  27  TA  projects.  ADB  TA  projects  are  listed  in  Supplementary 
Appendix K. 
 
42.  Sector Portfolio Description. The energy sector portfolio currently has no loans and 
seven ongoing TA projects, amounting to $3.95 million. Of the seven TA projects, five are 
operational while two are in the process of becoming operational and will field consultants in 
2006.  The  main  areas  covered  include  tariff  rationalization  and  integration,  management 
information  systems,  power  generation  coordination,  thermal  power  plant  maintenance, 
institutional strengthening and restructuring, and privatization.  
 
43.  Key Sector Portfolio Concerns. TA implementation performance is generally in line 
with Pakistan and ADB-wide averages. The country operational framework emphasizes the 
need  to  strengthen  governance  and  improve  on  portfolio  performance,  both  of  which  are 
important in the energy sector. 
 
44.  ADB Strategy. The energy sector in Pakistan needs to grow by 12% annually to sustain 
the envisaged GDP growth rate of 8% a year. The immediate demand for significant additional 
power will result in power shortages beginning in 2006–2007 and a shortfall of about 5,500 MW 
by 2009–2010, if no new investment takes place. ADB’s finance in the short- and medium-term 
will prioritize assistance for economic infrastructure projects that address critical gaps and 
constraints in the over-stressed transmission and distribution systems and that rehabilitate and 
modernize  the  power  infrastructure.  However,  investment  in  additional  generation  is  only 
justifiable if the transmission and distribution system can handle the additional load. ADB’s 
assistance to the energy sector also prioritizes power sector reform and renewable energy 
development.  
 
45.  Reforms to create an enabling environment for future public sector investment projects 
and to promote private sector participation have been made over the past 5 years. However, 
several challenges remain, and the sector continues to face high technical and financial losses, 
dependence on subsidies, overstaffing, and service deterioration. In the short term, ADB is 
helping the Government conduct sector analysis, capacity building and project identification, 
development, and implementation. Over the medium term, ADB will support larger infrastructure 
development projects in renewable energy, power transmission and distribution.  
 
46.  The Government has also been discussing possible technical assistance with ADB. 
Support for integrated energy modeling and planning capacity, energy subsector infrastructure 
development master plans, strengthening of institutional capacity to promote public–private 
partnership (particularly  the  independent  power  plants),  and  evaluation  of  opportunities  for 
energy cooperation in the South Asian Association of Regional Cooperation region are all under 
consideration. The Government is also likely to request ADB assistance for hydroelectric and 
water storage projects, energy (power, gas and liquefied natural gas) imports from Central Asia, 
and coastal oil refinery and petrochemical projects.    
 
47.  ADB’s  sector  strategy  recommends  careful  prioritization  of  new  public  sector 
investments, with an emphasis on creating a favorable environment for privatization and private 
sector involvement. Priority areas include (i) increasing energy efficiency (both supply and 
demand); (ii) optimizing hydropower and support for public–private partnerships in hydropower 
generation; (iii) balanced energy generation, transmission, and distribution; and (iv)  sector 
restructuring, rationalization of tariffs, and greater private sector participation.

10 
III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
48.  The proposed Investment Program is closely linked to Pakistan’s long-term power sector 
strategy  and  is  an  integral  part  of  the  power  transmission  development  program.  The 
Investment Program will enhance the efficiency of the overall power transmission system and 
provide an adequate and reliable power supply to a greater number of industrial, commercial 
and residential consumers. The power sector is a key infrastructure area for economic growth 
and development, and the Investment Program will be a vital way of supporting power sector 
development and economic growth in Pakistan. 
 
B.  Outputs 
49.  The  subprojects  under  the  proposed  Investment  Program  will  improve  power 
transmission infrastructure through rehabilitation, augmentation and expansion of the primary 
(above  220  kV)  transmission  network,  and  relieve  the  power  system  from  transmission 
bottlenecks. Specifically, (i) NTDC will adhere to its transmission license conditions and comply 
with the grid security code, (ii) about 10.5 gigawatt hours (GWh) of additional power will be 
supplied through the national grid annually, (iii) the system will be capable of meeting peak 
demand, with electricity outages significantly reduced; and (iv) 70 million additional people will 
have access to electricity from the national grid. 
 
50.  The Investment Program has two components. First, it will finance subprojects that are 
part of NTDC’s investment plan from ADB’s ordinary capital resources (OCR), through individual 
loans for each tranche. Second, it will finance an investment program support component from 
Asian Development Fund (ADF) resources, through a separate loan.  
 
C.  Technical Justification and Selection Criteria 
51.  The projects under the proposed Investment Program cover the whole country. The 
Investment Program is divided into tranches, with tranche 1 covering 19 subprojects and the 
investment program support component (Appendix 6). These subprojects are urgently needed 
for the system to meet the system safety and security requirements. The following criteria were 
used to identify the subprojects: (i) technical justification, (ii) financial and economic viability, 
and (iii) minimal residual environmental and social impacts.  
 
52.  Each  subproject  was  tested  for  financial  and  economic  viability,  and  assessed  for 
environmental or social impact. Load flow studies by NTDC tested the technical merits of 
subprojects and the results were verified by ADB. Most of the subprojects (15) in tranche 1 are 
additions or improvements to transformers within existing substations. Two subprojects contain 
a  new  substation,  with  an  associated  transmission  line  and  power  transformers,  and  one 
involves construction of a transmission line. A static var compensator (SVC) will be installed at 
an existing grid substation in tranche 1.  
 
53.  The requirements for justification will apply to all subprojects in the future tranches. 
NTDC is required under its license to meet the security standards governing planning and 
operation of the transmission system. However, it is finding it difficult to meet some of these 
standards,  which  could  result  in  a  breach  of  the  license  under  peak  conditions.  The 
reinforcements planned in tranches 1 and 2 will enable the security standards to be satisfied:

11 
(i)  15 subprojects will add transformers, as existing transformers are overloaded 
and the N-1 criteria is violated; 
(ii)  the two new substations will help to relieve the existing substation, which is 
overloaded under peak conditions; 
(iii)  the  Tarbela–Mardan  220  kV  double-circuit  transmission  line  will  relieve  the 
overloading of the circuit, thus meeting the N-1 criteria; and 
(iv)  the installation of the SVCs will help to reduce the voltage instability with the 
potential for cascade tripping and subsequent system collapse. 
 
D.  Subproject Preparation, Implementation, and Monitoring Capabilities 
54.  NTDC’s  experience  in  all  technical  aspects  of  power  transmission  is  satisfactory. 
However,  training  in  modern  transmission  planning  and  utility  management,  as  well  as  in 
information  and  communications  technology,  is  needed  to  bring  NTDC  up  to  date.  The 
investment program support component will strengthen NTDC’s project management, planning, 
design,  implementation  and  operation,  maintenance,  environmental  assessment,  and 
management  (Appendix  4).  The  support  component  will  improve  NTDC’s  subproject 
implementation  and  project  preparation.  Bilateral  exchange  programs  with  foreign  power 
transmission companies within and outside the region will develop role models among current 
and potential managers.  
 
55.  The investment program support component will help NTDC to prepare subprojects for 
tranche 3 onwards. It will also provide funding for the preparatory activities related to power 
evacuation  from  the  imported  coal  generation  project  proposed  for  the  Karachi  area.  The 
objective is to establish resources and capacity in NTDC to enable it to expand subproject 
preparation and implementation. Three streams of activities will be developed to  cover (i) power 
transmission  subproject  implementation,  including  general  business  management,  portfolio 
review,  project  management,  and  program  management;  (ii)  technical  operation  and 
maintenance;  (iii) accounting,  financial  and  economic  management,  and  financial  reporting; 
(iv) contracting, procurement, and inventory management, (v) management information system 
and economics of cost recovery and tariff setting; and (vi) project development, including policy 
development, feasibility studies, site identification, and project design. 
 
E.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 
56.  The total cost of the NTDC investment plan is $3.9 billion equivalent. The financing plan 
is a combination of funds from NTDC, ADB, and other financiers (Appendix 5). It was agreed 
that NTDC would provide at least 20% from its own resources and that ADB could fund up to 
80% of the total amount for each tranche.

57.  The Government has requested financing up to the equivalent of $800 million to help 
finance part of the NTDC investment plan. The financing will be provided under an MFF, in 
accordance with ADB policy.4  The implementation period will be 10 years. The MFF will consist 
of  individual  loans,  subject  to  the  submission  of  a  related  PFR  by  the  Government  and 
execution of Loan and Project Agreements. The Government has entered into a framework 
financing agreement (FFA) with ADB. The FFA satisfies the requirements set forth in Appendix 
4 of the ADB policy (footnote 4). The loans under the MFF will finance civil works, equipment 
and goods, and consulting services. The Government will make the proceeds of the loans 
available to NTDC upon terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB.   
 
58.  ADB will use its OCR to finance the subprojects for a maximum amount of $790 million. 
All of the provisions of the ordinary operations loan regulations applicable to a London interbank 
offered rate (LIBOR)–based loan5 will apply to each loan, subject to any modifications that may 
be included under individual Loan Agreements. Each loan will have a repayment period of 20 
years, including a grace period of 3 years, an interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s 
LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  a  commitment  charge  of  0.75%,  a  front-end  fee  of  1.0%,6 
conversion options that may be exercised in accordance with the terms of the FFA and the Loan 
Regulations, and such other terms set forth in the draft Loan and Project Agreements. The 
foreign risk will be borne by the Borrower. The Government has provided ADB with (i) the 
reasons  for  its  decision  to  borrow  under  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  and  (ii) an 
undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not made relying on any 
communication or advice from ADB.  
 
59.  The investment program support component, amounting to $10 million, will be funded by 
ADB through its ADF resources. The Borrower will make the proceeds of the loan available to 
NTDC upon terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB. Except as ADB may otherwise agree, the 
terms and conditions will include interest at the rate of 1% per annum during the grace period, 
and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and a repayment period of 32 years, including a grace period of 
8 years. The foreign exchange risk will be borne by the Borrower. The investment program 
support component will include all environmental and social safeguard aspects.  Projects will be 
prepared to attract and maximize investment from the private sector and from bilateral and 
multilateral financiers for the sizable subprojects needed in the later years of the investment 
plan.    
 
60.  The  Government  has  submitted  to  ADB  the  first  PFR  for  tranche  1,  requesting 
$226 million to finance 19 subprojects from ADB’s OCR resources and $10 million to finance the 
investment program support component from ADB’s ADF resources. The first PFR is presented 
to ADB’s Board of Directors together with this document and the FFA. The cost of the 19 
subprojects identified under tranche 1 is estimated at 2006 current prices to be $282 million. 
The Government and NTDC requested ADB to finance up to 80% of the total cost, amounting to 
$226 million. The remaining portion will be met by NTDC’s internally generated funds. The cost 
estimates per subproject are provided in Appendix 6.
