F.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  The Executing and Implementing Agencies 
61.  NTDC will be the Executing Agency (EA) and the Implementing Agency (IA).  
 
62.  NTDC has a well-established planning, services, and construction departments that will 
all be involved in the implementation of the MFF. A project management unit (PMU) will be 
established. The PMU manager will have been identified by the time of the Appraisal Mission. 
The PMU manager will report all subproject related matters to the general manager of the 
planning  department.  Once  the  Planning  Commission  Approval–1  (PC-1),  an  internal 
government approval for loan projects, (which will be developed by NTDC in a timely manner 
and submitted to the Government) has been approved by the Government, the PMU staff will be 
appointed. 
 
63.  Although a PMU has not been permanently established in NTDC, a number of key staff 
have already been assigned to carry out preparatory works, including (i) identification and   
preparation of subprojects, (ii) preparation and obtaining approval for the PC-1 from the federal 
government, (iii) assessment and approval for initial environmental examinations (IEEs) and 
resettlement plans by the provincial governments, and (iv) advance actions in procurement 
matters and recruiting consultants. The chief executive of NTDC has given a commitment that 
the PMU will have been officially established by 15 November 2006.  
 
64.  The subprojects will be implemented as per NTDC specifications. Relevant international 
practices and standards will be adhered to. Detailed construction and installation layout and 
drawings will be available for each subproject and will be in line with erection, construction, and 
commissioning  procedures  as  per  NTDC  standards  and  as  specified  in  specifications  and 
contracts. Environmental assessments will be carried out for each subproject in line with (i) the 
Government’s  Environmental  Protection  Agency  (EPA)  review  of  IEEs  and  environmental 
impact  assessment  (EIA)  regulations  2000,  and  (ii)  ADB’s  Environment  Policy  (2002)  and 
environment guidelines (2003). All subprojects will need to be submitted for approval to the 
provincial EPA (P-EPA). The Punjab EPA has indicated that, although all grid substations and 
11 kV transmission projects require environmental assessment under statutory provisions, this 
process need not be onerous and, providing all the subprojects are disclosed, the P-EPA will 
facilitate the environmental assessment approval process. A full EIA may not be required. 
NTDC will follow ADB’s policy on gender and development during the implementation of each 
subproject.  NTDC  will  also  monitor  the  effects  of  individual  subprojects  on  women  during 
implementation.  NTDC  will  further  ensure  that  all  bidding  processes  are  handled  in  a 
transparent manner and follow ADB’s guidelines in this regard. All resettlement issues will be

14 
dealt  with  within  the  resettlement  framework  and  the  resettlement  plan  prepared  for  each 
subproject.  NTDC  will  adhere  to  this  during  implementation.  NTDC  will  also  follow  the 
environmental assessment review framework, which was agreed with ADB. 
 
2.  Investment Program Management 
65.  The  Investment  Program  will  follow  MFF  implementation  procedures.  NTDC  will 
appraise  all  subprojects  and  be  responsible  for  processing  and  implementing  them.  The 
appraisal,  processing,  and  implementation  will  cover  the  development  and  completion  of 
technical  reports  (feasibility  studies,  preliminary  design  reports,  environmental  assessment 
reports, resettlement and indigenous people’s development plans, and detailed design reports) 
to ensure compliance with Government and ADB requirements. PFRs will be submitted to ADB 
when  they  have  been  approved  by  NTDC  and  have  received  the  required  government 
clearances (PC-1s). 
  
66.  NTDC will prepare progress reports and submit them to ADB every quarter. Rapid 
environmental  assessment  checklists  will  be  completed  as  an  early  warning  system  for 
subprojects that are environmental or social category A or B-sensitive. NTDC will submit other 
required performance and monitoring reports twice a year. Overall progress and compliance 
with  conditions  of  the  FFA  and  individual  loan  and  project  agreements  will  be  monitored 
regularly  with  periodic  reports  to  ADB,  consistent  with  existing  project  implementation 
requirements.  Reports  will  include  evaluation  of  issues  or  problems  faced  by  NTDC  and 
recommended  remedial  actions.  Overall  investment  progress  will  be  considered  as  new 
financing requests are submitted.  
 
3.  Implementation Period 
67.  The Investment Program will be implemented over 10 years, inclusive of procurement 
and construction activities, from 2007 to 2016 (Appendix 7). The loan agreements are expected 
to have implementation periods of 3–6 years. The last PFR should be submitted no later than 31 
December 2014.  
 
4.  Procurement and Consulting Services 
68.  Procurement of goods and services to be financed under the Investment Program will be 
implemented in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2006) and will be in line with 
ADB’s policy on environmentally responsible procurement. International competitive bidding 
(ICB) will be used for the supply of goods and works being funded under the Investment 
Program. ICB will be used for supply contracts estimated to cost the equivalent of $1 million or 
more. ICB will be used for works contracts estimated to cost the equivalent of $5 million or 
more. A procurement plan has been prepared to ensure there is maximum competition under 
international competitive bidding. The detailed thresholds of each procurement method are 
defined in Appendix 8. In accordance with the above arrangements, the tentative procurement 
packages for the subprojects under tranche 1 are also presented in Appendix 8.  
 
69.  Consulting services will be required for (i) preparation of subprojects, (ii) detailed design, 
and (iii) construction supervision and contract management. Consultants will be selected and 
engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2006). Firms carrying 
out consulting services will be selected through international competition using the quality- and 
cost-based selection method. Individual consultants may be recruited for specific assignments 
in accordance with the Government procedures acceptable to ADB. Because a number of tasks

15 
may continue over the course of implementation, it is envisioned that single-source selection 
may be used for some assignments with the prior approval of ADB. 
 
5.  Disbursement Arrangements 
70.  The  individual  loan  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Loan 
Disbursement  Handbook  (covering  both  ADF  and  OCR  resources)  and  ADB’s  Interim 
Guidelines for Disbursement Operations, LIBOR-Based Loan Products, both as amended from 
time to time.   
 
6.  Advance Contracting and Retroactive Financing 
71.  Because of the urgent nature of the subprojects, NTDC has requested ADB’s approval 
to carry out advance contracting for procurement of works and goods for each tranche. The 
Government has also requested retroactive financing of up to 20% of the loan amount for each 
tranche under the Investment Program. NTDC has been informed that approval of advanced 
contracting and retroactive financing does not commit ADB to finance any of the proposed 
subprojects.  
 
72.  ADB Management has approved the request for advanced contracting for procurement 
of works and goods. It has also agreed to seek Board approval for retroactive financing for the 
first and subsequent tranches (up to 20% of the proceeds from individual loans under the MFF) 
provided that expenditures are in accordance with agreed procedures and that they took place 
during the 12 months before the signing of the corresponding individual loan agreement and 
loan effectiveness under the MFF, subject to Management’s specific approval of retroactive 
financing  on  a  per-tranche  basis.  Retroactive  financing  is  sought  for  eligible  expenditures 
including  civil  works,  goods,  and  consulting  services.  Such  financing  will  be  subject  to 
compliance with involuntary resettlement requirements stated in subproject resettlement plan. 
  
7.  Anticorruption Policy  
 
73.  ADB’s anticorruption policy was explained to and discussed with the Government and 
NTDC. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, 
ADB  reserves  the  right  to  investigate,  directly  or  through  its  agents,  any  alleged  corrupt, 
fraudulent,  collusive,  or  coercive  practices  relating  to  subprojects  under  the  Investment 
Program.  To  support  these  efforts,  relevant  provisions  of  ADB’s  anticorruption  policy  are 
included in the loan regulations and the bidding documents for the Investment Program. In 
particular,  all  contracts  financed  by  ADB  in  connection with  the  Investment  Program  shall 
include provisions specifying the right of ADB to audit and examine the records and accounts of 
NTDC, and all contractors, suppliers, and consultants and other service providers as they relate 
to the Investment Program. 
 
8.  Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting  
 
74.  Quarterly progress reports will be prepared for the individual subprojects for review by 
ADB. The reports will include a description of physical progress, problems, and difficulties 
encountered and a summary of financial accounts that will consist of loan expenditures during 
the period, during the year to date, and the total to date. Progress on environmental and social 
compliance will be included. A subproject completion report will be submitted within 3 months 
following completion of each subproject. NTDC will maintain separate accounts for each loan. 
Within 6 months of the close of each fiscal year, NTDC will submit audited subproject accounts

16 
and financial statements to ADB. An independent auditor acceptable to ADB will be hired by 
NTDC to conduct the audit. 
 
75.  NTDC inherited an internal audit system from WAPDA.  The system provides for the 
internal audit to be involved in the procurement and disposal process as well as to perform 
annual  audits.  In  addition,  NTDC  has  established  an  audit  committee  with  an  external 
professional chairman.  This committee reports to the Board.  However, NTDC has not yet 
developed policies to fully reflect its independent status because of a lack of resources. The 
program support component includes provisions to hasten the development of audit policies and 
procedures and to strengthen the capacity of staff.   
 
G.  Performance Monitoring and Evaluation  
76.  The quarterly progress reports prepared by NTDC will provide (i) a narrative description 
of progress made during the period (progress on compliance with environmental and social 
requirements,  including  the  environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  and  resettlement 
framework, will also be included), (ii) changes in the implementation schedule, (iii) problems or 
difficulties encountered, and (iv) work to be carried out in the next period. The progress reports 
will also include a summary financial account for the subproject components, consisting of 
subproject expenditures during the period, total expenditure to date, and benefit monitoring in 
accordance with procedures and details acceptable to ADB. Performance will be evaluated on 
the basis of indicators and targets stipulated in the design and monitoring framework. ADB 
Management will prepare periodic reports to inform the ADB Board of Directors of overall 
progress. A Board information report will be submitted annually, and progress reports will be 
submitted to inform the Board of the approval of loan agreements. 
 
1.  Review  
77.  ADB will field an inception mission within 3 months of the first loan approval. It will 
review implementation and operations including resettlement, and environmental aspects based 
on quarterly progress reports. It will meet with the Government and NTDC semi-annually to 
discuss implementation progress. A midterm review will be carried out 2 years after each loan 
becomes effective. This will focus on the engineering, resettlement, environmental, and social 
aspects  of  ADB-supported  investments  and  review  the  financial  status  of  NTDC. 
Representatives of ADB and NTDC will take part in the review. The midterm review will evaluate 
compliance with warranties and representations of the FFA and, assurances in individual loan 
agreements.  The  review  will  allow  for  any  necessary  midcourse  corrections  to  ensure 
successful implementation and achievement of objectives. A project completion report will be 
submitted within 3 months of the completion of the subprojects financed under individual loan 
agreements. An Investment Program completion report will be prepared after the completion of 
all ADB-supported activities and projects under the Investment Program. 
 
IV.  INVESTMENT PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Investment Program Benefits and Beneficiaries 
78.  The  Investment  Program  is  designed  to  provide  all  grid-connected  consumers  with 
adequate and reliable supply of electricity, which will support the Government’s objective of 8% 
GDP growth per annum. Substantial investments in rehabilitation, augmentation, and expansion 
of the power transmission system will increase the reliability of supply to residential, agricultural, 
commercial, and industrial consumers in Pakistan. A secure and predictable electricity supply

17 
will lead to social and economic benefits and improve conditions for schools, hospitals, and 
other social services.     
 
B.  Technical Analysis 
79.  Subprojects were selected following a load flow study. The study was based on an 
expected 2013 conditions and follows the NTDC demand forecast for the system and the 
distribution companies. A least-cost expansion plan to meet the demand forecast was also used 
in the selection process. The subprojects were designed to address the problem areas identified 
by the load flow study. 
 
80.  The NTDC expansion program is based on the system load forecast. NTDC has also 
has developed a nationwide transmission development program for 2005–2025. A significant 
growth  in  electricity  demand  for  Pakistan  is  forecast.  To  meet  this  demand,  substantial 
investments  will  be  needed  to  strengthen  the  transmission  system  to  evacuate  the  power 
generated by the additional power plants. 
 
81.  NTDC has prepared load forecasts for the distribution companies.  These forecasts have 
been used for the subproject analysis and based on a high estimate of the distribution company 
demand.  
 
82.  NTDC has prepared a long-term system expansion plan which is based on significant 
additions  being  made  to  hydroelectric  power  generation,  the  number  of  coal-fired  thermal 
stations, and the number of independent power plants (IPPs) located in areas where there is 
not enough load. The plan assumes the mix of thermal and hydroelectric power will remain 
broadly the same as at present. However, this assumption may be affected by such significant 
variables  as  availability  of  imported  gas  and  domestic  coal,  and  the  addition  of  a  major 
hydroelectric power plant. These have the potential to cause a fundamental shift in the long-
term composition of the power mix, with a resultant change in the expansion of the primary 
transmission system. The subprojects to be included in the tranche 1 would not be affected by 
any drastic changes in the long-term system expansion plan. They have been selected to 
address previous inadequate planning, underinvestment, and lack of maintenance.  
 
83.  A  detailed  study  will  be  undertaken  by  NTDC  to  provide  details  of  the  connection 
between  the  planned  hydroelectric  development  in  the  north  and  the  planned  coal-based 
thermal expansion in the south. Load flow and transient studies will be carried out to assess the 
significance of the connection of IPPs. These studies will be used to provide subprojects for the 
second, third, and fourth tranches. 
 
C.  Financial Management and Financial Analysis 
84.  Financial management assessment has been carried out to evaluate NTDC’s ability to 
fulfill ADB’s fiduciary requirements. Questionnaires and field interviews were used to review 
current practice. NTDC is in transition and the assessment was designed to determine its 
potential to achieve financial and operational independence. Accounting diagnostic tools, such 
as the World Bank’s comprehensive country financial accountability assessment7 and public 
                                                 
7  World Bank. 2003. Islamic Republic of Pakistan, Country Financial Accountability Assessment. Washington, DC 
(December).

18 
expenditure review,8 and ADB technical assistance9 have been used to review NTDC’s financial 
systems.  The  review  has  identified  issues and  constraints  and  made  recommendations  to 
improve  budgeting,  accounting,  internal  controls,  funds  transfer,  audit,  and  legislative 
compliance to ensure that NTDC’s funds are efficiently and effectively utilized. 
 
85.  The financial management risk is considered acceptable. NTDC inherited a manual 
accounting system from WAPDA, which is being computerized. The head office has been 
computerized and this will be extended to the branches in due course. At the current level of 
tariff, NTDC is able to service and contribute the counterparty funds for tranche 1.  
 
86.  Financial  analysis  of  the  proposed  tranche  1  investments  has  been  carried  out  in 
accordance with the Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment 
Projects Financed by the Asian Development Bank.10 All financial costs and benefits have been 
expressed at constant 2006 prices. Cost streams used to determine the financial internal rate of 
return (FIRR), i.e. capital investment, operations and maintenance, insurance costs and taxes 
reflect the costs of delivering the estimated benefits. The current transmission tariff (use of 
system  charge)  was  used  to  estimate  the  revenue,  while  incremental  operation  and 
maintenance costs were charged for each year. 
 
87.  The FIRR of 24.7% compares favorably with the estimated weighted average cost of 
capital (WACC) of 8.1%, indicating financial viability for all tranche 1 subprojects. Financial 
viability  was  gauged  by  comparing  the  incremental  costs  and  benefits  of  with-project  and 
without-project  investment  scenarios.  The  incremental  benefits  arise  through  the  increased 
evacuation  of  power  through  the  transmission  system  due  to  the  removal  of  transmission 
constraints as a result of the investment. The tariff approved in January 2006 was used without 
any revision for the 30-year period that the FIRR was calculated for. Non-quantifiable financial 
benefits such as quality of power supply were not included in the financial evaluation.   
  
D.  Economic Analysis 
88.  The  proposed  investments  to  be  funded  by  ADB  are  least-cost.  They  are  part  of 
Pakistan’s  integrated  generation  and  transmission  expansion  program,  and  an  integral 
component of the transmission system development plan prepared by NTDC using least-cost 
planning  principles.  The  economic  analysis  was  based  on  a  “time-slice”  approach  to  the 
transmission  system  development  plan,  as  individual  subprojects  are  not  stand-alone 
investments and would not yield all their benefits if considered in isolation. The Investment 
Program will ease chronic supply shortages and help meet the projected growth in demand for 
electric power. Demand forecasts and cost–benefit projections were prepared and analyzed and 
the Investment Program was judged to be economically viable. A summary of the economic 
analysis is provided in Appendix 10.   
 
89.  The main benefits stem from (i) removing existing bottlenecks in order to meet growing 
energy needs by facilitating efficient and effective evacuation of power from existing power 
                                                 
8  World Bank. 2004. Pakistan Public Expenditure Management, Strategic Issues and Reform Agenda. Washington, 
DC (January). 
9  ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for Institutional Capacity Building of the 
National Transmission and Despatch Company Limited (Financed by the Japan Special Fund). Manila. 
10 ADB. 2002. Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by the 
Asian Development Bank. Manila.

19 
stations, (ii) improving the efficiency, reliability, and security of the system, (iii) evacuating power 
from additional power stations, and (iv) reducing losses.  
 
90.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was estimated to be 23.9%, based on the 
incremental  cost–benefit  streams  associated  with  the  Investment  Program.  Economic 
performance  was  evaluated  by  comparing  with-  and  without-project  scenarios.  The  EIRR 
compares the annual streams of economic capital and operating costs against benefits, based 
on willingness to pay. All costs, benefits, and revenues are expressed in 2006 constant prices. 
The analysis period includes the construction period and 30 years of operation. Economic 
benefits  accrue  to  consumers  and  the  economy  as  a  result  of  the  Investment  Program. 
Incremental consumption occurs because of the extended availability of adequate and reliable 
power supplies.  
  
E.  Environmental Assessment 
91.  Environmental assessment for all the subprojects will be conducted in accordance with 
the Environmental Assessment Review Framework (EARF), prepared by the Government and 
agreed with ADB, ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) and Environmental Assessment Guidelines 
(2003), and the Government’s environmental assessment regulations and guidelines (Pakistan 
Environmental Protection Act 1997). Of the tranche 1 subprojects, three of the 19 subprojects 
under the first PFR have been categorized as B and the other 16 have been categorized as C 
under ADB’s environment guidelines. Environmental assessments have been carried out for 
each subproject. An IEE report and an EMP with implementation budget have been prepared for 
the three category B subprojects. A review of environmental implications has been carried out 
for  the  category  C  subprojects  and  presented  in  the  feasibility  review  compiled  by  the 
consultants. The IEEs and reviews of environmental implications for all 19 subprojects are 
summarized in Supplementary Appendix C. 
 
92.  Subproject components have been redesigned, wherever possible, to minimize adverse 
environmental impacts. To mitigate the potential adverse impacts of the construction stage, 
detailed environmental management plans (EMPs) have been prepared and attached to the 
IEEs. No component of any subproject falls in an environmentally sensitive or protected area. 
The 16 category C subprojects are essentially installation of new equipment within existing 
substations. The 19 subprojects in tranche 1 are all a long way apart and therefore there is no 
significant potential for cumulative impacts in the design, construction operational phases. The 
objective of the Investment Program is to produce cumulative benefits to the transmission 
system in the operational phase. Therefore there is no negative impact on the sector and no 
sector impact is provided. 
 
93.  NTDC will implement and monitor the submission and clearance of IEEs and EIAs under 
statutory provisions. It will ensure that bidding documents and contracts include the mitigation 
measures required in the EMPs and that the mitigation measures are implemented by the 
contractors. The Investment Program requires the establishment of an environmental cell within 
NTDC, and the appointment of environmental and resettlement specialists. 
 
F.  Social Safeguards 
94.  Land acquisition and resettlement (LAR) is expected for those subprojects that will 
require the construction of new grid stations or transmission lines. Construction of new grid 
stations will have more intense impacts than transmission lines. The only permanent LAR 
impact of the lines will be connected to the acquisition of tower bases. It is expected that

20 
impacts on houses and resettlement will be minimal. The land acquisition and resettlement 
framework (LARF) for the Investment Program and the land acquisition and resettlement plans 
(LARP) for the Mardan and the Bandala subprojects, which are the only tranche 1 subprojects 
with LAR effects have been prepared by the NTDC and agreed with ADB. The appraisal of 
successive tranches will require a review of the resettlement framework and preparation of 
LARPs for all projects with LAR issues. Project civil works will need to comply with LARP 
requirements. The LARF is appended as an appendix to the FFA while the LARPs for Mardan 
and Bandala subprojects are included as Supplementary Appendix J and K, respectively. 
95.  Indigenous peoples will be affected only by projects in North-West Frontier Province’s 
tribal  areas.  The  indigenous  peoples  development  framework  (IPDF)  for  the  Investment 
Program has been prepared and agreed with the Government. Appraisal of successive tranches 
will require a review of the IPDF and the preparation of indigenous peoples development plans 
(IPDP)  or  appropriate  indigenous  peoples  action  plans  for  all  subprojects  with  indigenous 
peoples issues. Full IPDP implementation will be a condition of beginning project civil works. No 
indigenous  peoples  are  affected  by  tranche  1  subprojects,  the  IPDF  is  appended  as  an 
appendix to the FFA.  
 
G.  Poverty Assessment 
96.  The Investment Program is expected to result in more adequate and reliable electric 
services. Electricity will be evacuated through the enhanced 500 kV and 220 kV transmission 
lines and substations, ensuring unrestricted seasonal flows of electricity between the north and 
south of the country. This will contribute to the overall objective of meeting peak demand all 
year  around  and  providing  sufficient  electricity  to  support  expected  accelerated  economic 
growth. 
 
97.  Greater access to reliable electricity generated by the Investment Program will contribute 
to poverty reduction. Poor and vulnerable consumers, including hospitals, schools, and other 
social utilities, are often hardest hit by inadequate power supply, load shedding, and poor power 
quality. They will benefit directly from the investments.  
 
98.  Improved power supplies will induce light industrial and commercial activity, creating 
employment  opportunities  and  improving  productivity  and  the  quality  of  outputs  in  the 
manufacturing and agriculture sectors. The Investment Program is expected to create new full-
time employment opportunities. About 250 workers will be hired to conduct civil works under 
each tranche. Indirect positive impacts will result from the supply of power to the national grid, 
allowing local governments to generate income that can be targeted specifically for social 
development in the state, particularly for the poor. 
 
H.  Potential Risks and Assumptions 
99.  Key  assumptions  are  (i)  macroeconomic  growth  will  remain  stable;  (ii)  federal  and 
provincial  governments  will  remain  committed  to  power  sector  reforms  and  there  will  be 
continued progress on policy, regulatory, and institutional reforms; and (iii) counterpart funds will 
be mobilized in a timely manner. 
 
100.  Risks to the Investment Program include (i) delays in power sector reforms, both in tariff 
determinations and in notifications of the rates applicable to the distribution companies by 
NEPRA  and  the  Government;  (ii)  delays  in  tariff  determinations  and  notifications  of  rates 
applicable  for  NTDC’s  wheeling  charges  by  NEPRA  and  the  Government,  to  facilitate

21 
investments in power transmission facilities; (iii) increases in prices of cement, steel, fuel, and 
other raw materials that would render the Investment Program financially non-viable; (iv) delays 
in subproject implementation; (v) failure to complete environmental and social assessments and 
to  actively  pursue  and  secure  environmental  clearances  for  all  subprojects  before 
commencement of construction; and (vi) failure to mobilize the necessary counterpart funds. 
These risks all appear low: NTDC is committed to expanding power supply within Pakistan 
through  increased  investments  in  transmission  facilities.  The  lack  of  capacity  in  NTDC  to 
facilitate environmental compliance is a concern, but this can be mitigated by making dedicated 
resources and staffing a condition of the loan, as specified in the FFA. Risk analyses will be 
expanded to include sensitivity analyses at a later stage of Investment Program processing.  
 
101.  Specific assumptions for the subprojects under the tranche 1 are (i) counterpart funds 
will be made available in a timely manner; (ii) there will be no delay in the notification of 
distribution company tariffs; and (iii) the Central Power Purchasing Agency (CPPA) will be 
established and empowered in a timely fashion, since without it the financial viability of NTDC 
cannot be ensured. The risks are (i) there will be a delay in recruitment of consultants and in 
procurement of turnkey contracts in the approval process within the federal government and 
NTDC; and (ii) prices of equipment and materials, such as cement, steel, fuel, and other raw 
materials, will increase, possibly making the subprojects financially non-viable. Contingency 
funds will be allocated to respond to any unforeseen changes. 
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
A.  Specific Assurances 
102.  The  Government  and  NTDC  have  agreed  to  the  following  specific  assurances,  in 
addition  to the  standard  assurances  and  assurances  agreed  to  in the  FFA,  which  will  be 
incorporated in the legal documents.  
 
103.  Policy Dialogue. The Government will ensure that ADB is kept informed about the 
Government’s policies and programs related to the power sector that will materially affect the  
financial viability of each subproject under the Investment Program, and in particular the power 
generation policies and program, as well as the power transmission policies and program.  
 
104.  Tariff. NTDC will submit a petition for tariff revision as required to maintain its financial 
viability. Following tariff determination by NEPRA, the Government will undertake to notify such 
tariff determination in a prompt manner. The Government will ensure that the tariff formulated 
for NTDC is adequate to cover its operating costs, maintenance, depreciation, and financing 
cost and to allow an acceptable return on the equity of NTDC. 
 
B.  Counterpart Funding 
105.  The Government will ensure, and cause NTDC to ensure, the availability and timely 
release of counterpart funding for the timely implementation of subprojects financed under the 
Investment Program. 
 
C.  Financial Management and Performance Indicators 
106.  Establishment of CPPA. The Government, through MOWP, and NTDC will ensure that 
the CPPA is established as an entity that is independent from NTDC and that all of the trade 
debt incurred by NTDC for its single buyer role is transferred to CPPA or otherwise separated

22 
from NTDC.  The Government, through MOWP, will cause CPPA to define its corporate identity, 
devise a business plan and a strategic development road map to have a single corporate body 
accountable for the single buyer business. NTDC will ensure it submits to NEPRA an application 
to revise its license to reflect the establishment of CPPA as a separate entity from NTDC. 
 
107.  Financial Performance. The Government will ensure that NTDC will maintain a debt 
service coverage ratio of at least 1.2 from 2010 onward and a self-financing ratio of at least 20% 
from 2008 onward. 
 
108.  Financial Autonomy. The Government will ensure that NTDC bills the paying authority 
directly and in a timely manner for the transmission services render to its customers. The 
Government will ensure that the paying authority provides prompt payment to NTDC, and in 
case of any shortfall from the paying authority, the Government will finance such shortfall in a 
timely manner. 
 
109.  Auditing and Accounting. NTDC will ensure that proper accounts and records are 
maintained in a timely manner to adequately identify the use of tranche proceeds in such a 
manner and details as may be specified in each Loan Agreement and Project Agreement. 
Audited financial reports of NTDC will be submitted to ADB within 6 months of fiscal year end. 
 
110.  Financial Governance. NTDC will ensure that its internal controls are in accordance 
with the National Accounting Standards and an independent and autonomous internal audit 
department will be set up within NTDC. 
 
D.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
111.  NTDC will ensure that (i) all land and rights-of way required by the subprojects are made 
available in a timely manner; (ii) the provisions of the resettlement plans are implemented 
promptly and efficiently according to its terms, all applicable laws and regulations of Pakistan, 
ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement (1995), and the land acquisition and resettlement 
framework  (LARF);  (iii)  the  resettlement  plans  are  updated  based  on  the  detailed  design, 
prepared in full consultation with the affected persons and disclosed to them prior to submitting 
the resettlement plans to ADB; (iv) the commencement of civil work or a similar milestone will be 
subject to ADB’s review and approval of the relevant resettlement plans; (v) the contractors’ 
activities are in compliance with requirements of the resettlement plans, the LARF, applicable 
domestic laws, and ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement; (vi) an independent monitor 
acceptable to ADB is engaged to carry out monitoring and evaluation and report to ADB in 
accordance with the requirements of the resettlement plans. 
 
E.  Indigenous Peoples 
112.  NTDC will ensure that all subprojects affecting ethnic minorities are constructed and 
operated in accordance with the requirements of ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998) as 
specified in the Indigenous Peoples Development Framework (IPDF) agreed with ADB and the 
Indigenous Peoples Development Plans (or resettlement plans). NTDC shall ensure that the 
Ethnic Minorities Development Plans (or resettlement plans) are monitored and evaluated by an 
independent agency.

23 
F.  Environment 
113.  NTDC will ensure that (i) the subprojects are constructed and operated in accordance 
with national and local environmental procedures and guidelines and with ADB’s Environment 
Policy (2002); (ii) the subprojects are designed, constructed, and operated in accordance with 
the environment management plans (EMPs) as reflected in the initial environment examinations 
and the Environment Assessment Review Framework; (iii) the EMPs will be incorporated in 
bidding  documents  and  civil  work  contracts  and  implemented;  and  (iv)  environmental 
performance reports will be submitted to ADB twice annually during the construction period, 
including progress made on the mitigation measures, monitoring data, problems encountered, 
enforcement plan, and any violations. 
 
G.  Social Impacts 
114.  Gender. NTDC will follow the principles of the ADB’s policy on gender and development 
during each subproject implementation, including taking all necessary actions to encourage 
women living in the subproject area to participate in planning and implementing subproject 
activities.  NTDC  will  monitor  the  subproject  effects  on  women  during  each  subproject 
implementation, through, where relevant, gender-disaggregated data collected pursuant to the 
monitoring and evaluation system referred to in the subproject performance monitoring system. 
 
115.  Sexually Transmitted Diseases. With the assistance of the relevant local authorities, 
NTDC  will  cause  contractors  to  distribute  information  on  the  risks  of  sexually  transmitted 
diseases to those employed during each subproject construction. 
 
116.  Women and Child Labor. NTDC will ensure that (i) there is no differential payment 
between men and women for work of equal value, and (ii) civil works contractors do not employ 
child labor in the construction and maintenance activities in accordance with the relevant laws 
and regulations of the Government. 
 
H.  Execution of Civil Works Contracts 
117.  NTDC will ensure that, subsequent to award of civil works contract under any subproject, 
no section or part thereof under the civil works contract will be handed over to the contractor 
unless the applicable provisions of the LARF and Resettlement Plans, including in particular the 
timely  delivery  of  compensation  to  affected  families,  Indigenous  Peoples  Development 
Framework  and  Indigenous  Peoples  Development  Plans,  and  the  EAF/EMPs  have  been 
complied with. 
 
118.  Any changes to the location, land alignment of facilitating roads, or environment impacts 
on account of detailed designs of related subprojects will be subject to prior approval by ADB or 
related agency in accordance with the subproject selection criteria and procedures included in 
the FFA. 
 
I.  Subproject Selection Criteria 
119.  The Government and NTDC shall ensure that all subprojects are selected in accordance 
with the agreed criteria set out in the FFA, which adhere to the relevant requirements of the 
power  transmission  investment  plan  and  other  applicable  guidelines  for  subproject 
implementation.  NTDC  will  monitor  the  implementation  of  subprojects  through  to  their 
completion of each subproject.

J.  Conditions for Loan Effectiveness 
1.  Conditions for the first tranche 
120.  The ADF and OCR loans shall be declared effective at the same time. 
 
2.  Conditions for the second tranche 
121.  Corporate Governance. The Government will ensure that no person serving on the 
board of NTDC, WAPDA, a DISCO, or GENCO concurrently is a board member of any

122.  Tariff. The Government will cause the DISCOs to submit petitions for tariff revisions, as

Appendix 2  27 
POWER SECTOR ASSESSMENT 
 
A.  Overview 
1.  Pakistan’s power sector faces tremendous challenges: (i) generation capacity needs to 
be increased, (ii) constraints in the transmission and distribution systems have to be overcome, 
(iii)  financial  management  must  be  improved  and  the  sustainability  of  the  sector  entities 
assured, and (iv)  proper corporate governance structures for the successor companies have to 
be put in place.  
 
2.  The Government of Pakistan has approved policies, strategies, and action plans for the 
power  sector  to  (i)  ensure  independent  regulation  of  the  power  sector;  (ii)  complete  the 
unbundling of the Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA), establish four generation 
and  eight  distribution  companies,  and  the  National  Transmission  and  Despatch  Company 
(NTDC); (iii) commence the power sector privatization program; and (iv) evaluate and optimize 
the fuel sources available to the power sector to ensure energy security and minimize overall 
tariff requirements.  
 
3.  The power sector will need to increase its capacity if the economic growth targets in the 
Medium-Term  Development  Framework,  2005–2010  (MTDF)  are  to  be  achieved  and  the 
poverty reduction strategy of the Government implemented. Currently, about 45% of Pakistan’s 
population has no access to electricity from the national grid. Existing bottlenecks in the power 
transmission network are expected to result in significant system capacity shortfalls, which in 
turn could restrict the GDP growth by almost 0.8% in fiscal year (FY) 2008. 
 
4.  Transmission and distribution losses in the Pakistan power system amounted to 25% in 
2005. In the transmission system, these high losses are caused by the excess load on the 
transmission lines and at substations. Total transmission losses are 7.5%, including secondary 
transmission system losses. Primary system losses are about 3.0%. The transmission system is 
aging,  overloaded,  and  poorly  maintained.  It  is  unreliable,  and  at  times  there  is  a  risk  of 
collapse. The system needs immediate rehabilitation, augmentation, and expansion to provide 
services so it can meet consumer demands and system security requirements. The safe and 
reliable transmission of electricity remains a major challenge for Pakistan.  
 
B.  Background  
1.  Sector Policy 
5.  In  2000,  the  Government  unveiled  the  “Vision  2025”  program  which  advocated 
accelerated development of new generation facilities. This was revised in 2002, with greater 
reliance placed on indigenous fuel sources—hydropower, thermal generation using local coal 
reserves or local gas supplies, and renewable technologies. 
  
6.  The 2002–2004 power policy includes an increase in power generation capacity and 
encompasses private, public and private–public models. The policy continues the underlying 
theme of Vision 2025 by encouraging the use of indigenous resources, principally hydroelectric 
power and coal. A number of thermal and hydroelectric projects are currently being processed 
under the policy.

28  Appendix 2 
2.  Sector Strategy 
7.  The Government’s strategy for the power sector has three main intended outcomes: 
(i) sector reforms to create an enabling environment for private sector participation; (ii) more 
capacity  building  in  all  sector  organizations,  including  financial  management,  efficiency 
improvement,  use  of  the  clean  development  mechanism,  and  project  management;  and 
(iii) completion of large infrastructure development projects in generation, transmission, and 
distribution. 
 
8.  The MTDF contains a medium- and long-term integrated national energy security plan 
for the country. The objectives of the MTDF are (i) to increase power generation; (ii) to enhance 
the exploitation and production of oil, gas, and coal resources and to increase the share of coal 
and alternative energy in the energy mix; (iii) to optimize the use of indigenous sources and 
reduce dependence upon imported sources; and (iv) to encourage and facilitate private sector 
involvement. Table A2.1 shows how the MTDF envisages that the primary energy mix will 
evolve over time. The strategy for bridging the energy gap assumes that gas will be imported 
from four different sources. Two gas pipelines are planned for 2015, a third for 2020, and a 
fourth for 2030. Any remaining deficit will be met by oil imports. The resulting power generation 
plan is presented in Table A2.2. To address the overloading of the NTDC network, MTDF 
recommends the addition of four transmission lines and six grid stations to the 500 kV and 220 
kV systems.

9.  The  MTDF  also  sets  out  an  investment  strategy  for  the  power  transmission  and 
distribution sectors. It recognizes that the existing transmission infrastructure and grid stations 
are  overloaded,  that  the  south–north  and  north–south  transmission  systems  need  to  be 
strengthened, and that new generation projects need to be connected to the national grid. The 
MTDF also address the problems of the distribution network, including overloaded substations 
and high distribution losses, and recommends that the network be expanded and efficiency

Appendix 2  29 
improved. The MTDF makes other recommendations, among them to (i) ensure independent 
regulation of the power sector, (ii) unbundle WAPDA and establish and fully operationalize the 
successor companies, and (iii) strengthen the privatization program. The MTDF also specifies 
the need to further strengthen the regulatory role of the National Electric Power Regulatory 
Authority (NEPRA).  
 
3.  Major Stakeholders 
a.  Ministry of Water and Power 
10.  The Ministry of Water and Power (MOWP) is the federal government agency responsible 
for all policy matters related to the water and power sectors, and for overall supervision of the 
performance of organizations under its administrative control. In addition to its responsibility for 
policy, MOWP performs certain specific functions, such as carrying out strategic and financial 
planning for public and private involvement in the sector. Proposals for power sector projects 
are scrutinized in MOWP, which assesses their technical and financial viability and adherence 
to the overall strategic plan. Private sector projects in the power sector are processed by the 
Private  Power  Investment  Board  (PPIB),  supervised  by  MOWP,  which  establishes  policy 
guidelines  for  the  approval  of  private  projects.  Five-year  plans  and  annual  development 
programs in water and power sector are all overseen by MOWP. MOWP also monitors activities 
in power generation, transmission and distribution and performs a supervisory and advisory role 
in ensuring the smooth operation of the power sector.  
 
b.  National Electric Power Regulatory Authority 
11.  The  National  Electric  Power  Regulatory  Authority  (NEPRA)  was  established  by  the 
Regulation of Generation, Transmission and Distribution of Electric Power Act, 1997 (Electric 
Power Act). It was created to introduce transparent and judicious economic regulation, based on 
sound commercial principles, to the electric power sector. It performs three main regulatory 
functions: (i) licensing of generation, transmission and distribution of electric power; (ii) tariff 
determination; and (iii) setting of market rules and operating standards. Over the last 5 years, 
NEPRA has established its regulatory credentials. ADB provided institutional capacity support to 
NEPRA in 2000 and 2001 through a technical assistance project.1 With regard to tariff setting, 
NEPRA is moving toward full cost recovery, although some of the tariff determinations have 
favored consumers and have contributed to the poor financial performance of power companies 
and investors. NEPRA issues licenses to generation, transmission, and distribution companies, 
as well as making tariff determinations. Tariff determinations are notified by the Government 
and then become effective.  
 
c.  Water and Power Development Authority  
12.  The Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) was established by the Water 
and  Power  Development  Authority  Act,  1958.  Its  responsibilities  include  generation, 
transmission  and  distribution  of  power,  along  with  additional  responsibilities  for  irrigation, 
drainage and flood control. It owns about 58% of the country’s total power generation capacity 
and serves over 13 million customers, representing 88% of all the electricity customers in the 
country.  Between  1984  and  2005,  WAPDA’s  total  installed  power  generating  capacity 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2000. Technical Assistance to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for Capacity Building of the National Electric 
Power Regulatory Authority. Manila.

30  Appendix 2 
quadrupled from 4,339 MW to 17,405 MW, of which 5,783 MW was generated by independent 
power producers (IPP). Thermal power plants contributed 70% of the increase, hydroelectric 
power plants 27.5%, and nuclear power plants, 2.5%. 
 
13.  Following  the  passing  of  the  Electric  Power  Act  of  1997,  the  power  sector  was 
unbundled  from  WAPDA.  Under  business  transfer  agreements,  most  assets  have  been 
transferred to new companies. Initially the shares of the companies were held by WAPDA. To 
increase the independence of the companies these shares are now in the name of the President 
of Pakistan. The voting rights of the shares and the nomination rights for the board members of 
the companies have been delegated to the Chairman of the Pakistan Electric Power Company 
(PEPCO), in accordance with a presidential directive.  
 
d.  Pakistan Electric Power Company  
14.  PEPCO was established in 1998 following the Government’s decision to amend its 
strategic privatization plan. PEPCO has been entrusted with the task of managing the transition 
of WAPDA from a monopolistic structure to a corporate, commercially viable and productive 
entity.  This  has  involved  (i)  deregulation  of  the  power  sector,  (ii)  promotion  of  IPPs,  (iii) 
restructuring of WAPDA, and (iv) privatization of select corporate entities.  
 
15.  Policy on WAPDA was amended because (i) despite the increase in generation capacity 
unmet  demand  still  existed;  and  (ii)  WAPDA's  growth  had  caused  inefficiencies,  “demand 
suppression”, a high-tariff policy, and theft of power. All these factors had adversely affected 
WAPDA's financial condition. 
 
16.  WAPDA's functions under its water and power wings were to be segregated. It was 
previously envisaged that all power generation, hydro as well as thermal, would be corporatized. 
However, it has now been decided that hydro generation should remain part of the water wing of 
the remaining WAPDA. 
 
e.  National Transmission and Despatch Company 
17.  The National Transmission and Despatch Company (NTDC) is a public limited company 
incorporated in Pakistan in November 1998. It began commercial operations in March 1999. 
NTDC was granted a transmission license on 31 December 2002 by NEPRA to engage as the 
exclusive transmission company for Pakistan for a term of 30 years, pursuant to section 17 of 
the Electric Power Act of 1997. Under this license, NTDC will undertake three specific functions: 
(i)  high-voltage  transmission  of  power  (220  kV  and  above),  (ii)  the  dispatch  of  all  power 
generation linked to the national grid, and (iii) the single purchaser and seller of power.  
 
18.  As the sole transmission company in Pakistan, NTDC is responsible for (i) maintaining 
and  upgrading  the  current  system;  (ii)  planning,  designing,  and  implementing  system 
expansions;  and  (iii)  operating  the  system  dispatch  generation  according  to  system 
requirements and transmission license conditions. The company took over properties, rights, 
assets, obligations, and liabilities of 220 kV and 500 kV grid stations and transmission lines and 
networks owned by WAPDA under a business transfer agreement dated 1 March 1999.   
 
19.  MOWP has determined that the single-buyer function licensed to NTDC will be handled 
by an independent agency, the Central Power Purchasing Agency (CPPA). This function is 
being transferred from NTDC. A new license will have to be issued to NTDC and possibly the 
CPPA. As an interim measure, CPPA will be managed separately within NTDC. WAPDA Private

Appendix 2  31 
Power Organization (WPPO) will be restructured to take on the task of the CPPA. Terms of 
reference for the management of the independent CPPA have been drafted. ADB has been 
requested to provide technical assistance for the establishment and start of operations of CPPA.  
 
f.  Private Sector Participation 
20.  The  Government  appreciates  the  need  for  private  sector  participation  in  the  power 
sector. In 2002, it set out policy for power generation projects, which provided a clear set of 
incentives, along with a regulatory regime. This effectively created a framework to attract private 
capital.  In  order  to  facilitate  private  sector  participation  in  power  generation,  transmission 
systems must be stable and reliable and new investments must be made to respond to the 
additional  generated  capacity.  Pakistan  has  been  successful  in  attracting  private  sector 
investment and is working to further improve the enabling environment.2 Independent power 
producers account for about 30% of electricity generating capacity. 
 
21.  The Government established the Private Power Infrastructure Board (PPIB) in 1994. The 
PPIB provides a “one-window” facility to private sector investors in matters concerning the 
establishment  of  power  projects  and  related  infrastructure,  including  negotiation  of  the 
implementation agreement. The PPIB also provides support to the power purchaser and fuel 
supplier in negotiating power purchases and fuel or gas supply agreements, and in liaising with 
the  local  and  international  agencies  concerned.  With  Government  approval,  PPIB  is  also 
responsible for formulating, reviewing and updating policies and procedures relating to private 
sector investments in the power sector. 
 
22.  The PPIB has facilitated investments of over $4 billion from the commercial sector. All 
power purchase agreements have government guarantees. As a condition for private sector 
investment in generation, a reliable and sustained ability to evacuate the power from IPPs as 
well as delivery of the power to the end users is necessary. The power transmission investment 
plan will remove potential bottlenecks and ensure the evacuation of power generated by IPPs 
and new public power generation facilities. A number of new IPP projects may also include 
transmission  components.  NTDC  will  actively  seek  commercial  investments  in  the  larger 
transmission projects.  
 
C.  Sector Issues  
1.  Key Opportunities and Challenges 
23.  Pakistan is a net importer of energy. During FY2000-2005, it spent about $3.3 billion a 
year, equivalent to 22–25% of total imports, to import oil to meet its energy needs. In the first 9 
months of FY2006, Pakistan's oil imports amounted to $4.6 billion, and for the full year, the total 
is expected to exceed $6.0 billion. Oil importation places a heavy burden on foreign exchange 
reserves and recent increases in oil prices and price volatility complicate this problem. Most of 
imported  energy  is  for  electricity  generation.  Even  with  all  this  imported  energy,  there  is 
suppressed  demand  and  the  power  system  is  unable  to  respond  to  peak  demand  (partly 
because of lack of capacity at peak summer and winter periods). The winter peak demand is

Cluster of Loans and Technical Assistance Grant to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for Private Participation in 
Infrastructure Program. Manila.

32  Appendix 2 
putting thermal plants under pressure as increases to thermal generation have been insufficient. 
About 45% of Pakistan’s population has no access to electricity from the national grid and uses 
kerosene, fuel wood, and other forms of bio-fuels for lighting, cooking, and heating. Pakistan’s 
per capita energy consumption is one of the lowest in the world. 
 
24.  The electricity market has been characterized in recent years by marked changes in the 
primary energy sources used to produce electricity. In FY1995, hydropower still accounted for 
nearly 50% of electricity generated by generation companies, but by 2005 that share had 
dropped to 30%. Over the same period, the share of thermally generated electricity increased 
from 50% to 65%, the result of capacity additions since the early 1990s. 
 
25.  Electricity consumption has grown steadily in recent years. From 1995 to 2005, total 
consumption increased by more than 58%, from 35 to 55 terawatt hours (TWh) per year, with 
the domestic sector accounting for the largest proportion of consumption, followed by industry 
and then agriculture. The demand for electricity is forecast to continue to rise. 
 
26.  To  meet  the  projected  increase  in  demand  of  around  10,000  MW  by  2010,  the 
Government has launched a large-scale generation expansion program. Nevertheless, power 
shortages  are  anticipated.  To  minimize  future  supply  deficits,  Pakistan  has  adopted  a 
systematic development plan called “Vision 2025” that targets a long-term capacity increase of 
around 35,000 MW by 2025 (almost double the capacity in 2002). 
 
27.  About two thirds of the additional power (22,563 MW) will come from hydroelectric 
sources, while new gas-fired power plants will contribute 13% (4,680 MW), about the same as 
that generated by coal-fired power plants (4,350 MW). New nuclear power plants, with a total 
installed capacity of 1,800 MW (5%), are also planned. Finally, it is intended that renewable 
sources of energy will account for more than 4% (1,500 MW) of the overall newly installed 
capacity. The planned expansion will cost approximately $30 billion. 
 
28.  Natural gas-fired plants have operated almost exclusively on domestic resources, as 
have most of Pakistan’s coal-fired power plants. However, this policy of reliance on indigenous 
resources is being reassessed in the light of increasing demands for electricity. 
 
29.  Several board members and staff members hold concurrent positions on the boards of 
the unbundled entities. This is not ideal from the corporate governance stand point. Because of 
the  inherent  conflicts  of  interest  between  WAPDA,  distribution  companies,  generation 
companies, and NTDC, such concurrent memberships may make it difficult for board members 
to fulfill their fiduciary duty to act solely for the benefit of each entity. 
 
2.  Financial Issues 
30.  The  power  sector  needs  sustainable  tariff  arrangements  and  resolution  of  the 
receivables  from  distribution  companies  as  well  as  payments  to  generation  companies  for 
electricity  supplied.  NTDC  plays  a  central  role  between  the  generation  and  distribution 
companies but its single buyer function has made the company financially unsound. Most of the 
PRs14 billion in losses incurred by NTDC in 2005 was because of the single buyer function. The 
2005  accounts  for  NTDC  also  show  that  the  cost  of  electricity  owed  to  the  generation 
companies was PRs192 billion but sales were only PRs189 billion. This PRs3 billion loss plus 
the operation and financing cost make up the loss for the single buyer function. There are also 
outstanding  receivables  from  the  distribution  companies.  The  disparity  in  receivables  and 
payables are caused in part by the current tariff arrangement. Distribution companies have not

Appendix 2  33 
been able to charge cost recovery rates where as generation companies and IPPs have had 
cost adjustments for their tariffs. The tariff determination was made for WAPDA and not the 
distribution companies. The deficit amount covered by the Government is a subsidy to the 
electricity consumers. Cost increases in the electricity generated by thermal plants because of 
increases in fuel prices, will strain Government finances unless the distribution tariff is increased 
to cost recovery levels.  
 
31.  The current Government relending rate to NTDC is 17%, pursuant to a government 
circular of 1996. The rate paid by NTDC for its commercial borrowing is currently about 12%. In 
1996 the commercial lending rate was over 20% and, considering the foreign exchange risk the 
Government  was  taking,  17%  seemed  to  be  justified.  However,  when  commercial  rates 
decreased,  the  Government’s  relending  rate  was  not  revised  so  as  to  instill  commercial 
discipline in state-owned entities by forcing them to borrow from the market. This matter is 
currently under review by the Ministry of Finance. 
 
D.  Transmission Issues 
1.  Key Opportunities and Challenges 
32.  Pakistan’s power transmission system faces three major challenges: (i) the heavy power 
flow through the 500 kV system, (ii) a shortage of supply capacity for the 220 kV system, and 
(iii) high transmission losses. Hydropower plants are located mainly in the northern parts of the 
country and the thermal plants are primarily located in the south. There is a heavy power flow 
from north to south during summer when hydropower generation is high, and a heavy flow from 
south to north in winter when hydropower generation is low.  
 
33.  According to Government estimates, electricity demand in Pakistan is forecast to grow 
by at least 8% a year during 2005–2015. To meet this increasing demand, it is estimated that 
Pakistan would require an additional 2,000 MWs annually, which would need to be evacuated 
through  the  transmission  system.  Substantial  investments  are  required  to  strengthen  the 
transmission system to (i) urgently address current shortfalls and quality problems, (ii) evacuate 
power generated by additional power plants, and (iii) supply electricity to meet the growing 
demand. 
 
34.  The  mismatch  between  the  location  of  demand  and  the  source  of  supply  requires 
investments in the primary network. Current peak energy and capacity shortfalls are to some 
extent the consequence of shortages and bottlenecks in the national network. Primary network 
constraints cause inefficiencies at the consumers, such as high levels of un-served energy or 
investment in costly self- or captive generation, at a significant cost. For example, the export 
competitiveness of the textile sector is eroded by high electricity costs and unreliable supplies.  
 
35.  Because of the weak grid infrastructure and substantial thefts of electricity, losses from 
the ex-WAPDA transmission and distribution network amounted to some 25% in 2005. Total 
transmission losses are 7.5%, including the secondary transmission system losses. The primary 
system losses are about 3.0%.  
 
36.  High  growth  in  electricity  demand  in  Pakistan  is  clearly  putting  the  existing  power 
transmission infrastructure under severe stress. There is a clear need to invest in additional

34  Appendix 2 
primary transmission facilities.  The Power Transmission Sector Road Map for 2007–2016 
(Appendix 3) is a comprehensive plan that specifies the details of system renovation and 
expansion and makes recommendations on how a reliable and high-quality power supply can 
be  delivered  to  the  growing  number  of  industrial,  commercial,  agricultural,  and  domestic 
customers. It is consistent with the Government’s poverty reduction strategy, which aims to 
increase the level of economic activity. It has the following intended outcomes: (i) a more 
efficient power system; (ii) high-quality power supply through a more reliable and stable system; 
(iii) greater  geographic  coverage;  and  (iv)  more  availability  of  and  access  to  affordable 
electricity, by bringing hydroelectric and coal-fired thermal energy to load centers.  
 
2.  Transmission System Overview 
37.  The currently installed generation capacity of the ex-WAPDA companies amounts to 
17,405 MW. Available generation capacity is about 13,000 MW because (i) hydropower plants 
are  dependent  upon  reservoir  capacity  and  hence  rainfall,  reservoir  silting,  and  irrigation 
priorities; (ii) the generation portfolio is ageing and subject to rating limitations and maintenance 
requirements; and (iii) there are increased forced outage expectations.  
 
38.  The immediate concern is the capacity of the transmission network to evacuate and 
transmit the present available generation output to load centers. The maximum transmission 
system demand of 13,051 MW recorded in summer 2006 is believed to represent the system at 
full capacity, or over full capacity according to safety and sustainability standards. This is a 
constrained maximum demand that is based on the capacity of the transmission network. It has 
been estimated that at that time there was 800 MW of unsatisfied demand. Sections of the 
transmission network are known to be running periodically above rating limits, increasing the 
risk of forced and lengthy transmission outages.  
 
39.  The load shed at generation, primary transmission and secondary transmission level is 
estimated to be about 800 MW. This load shedding figure does not include the “load shed” due 
to under-frequency and low voltage. This seasonal generation gap between supply and demand 
at present and in the near future is presented in Table A2.3.

the location of the power generation potential in the north (hydroelectric), south (coal) and west

compared with local demand). The development of hydroelectric potential in the north and of

Appendix 2  37 
coal  resources  in  the  south  reflects  the  Government’s  policy  of  reliance  on  indigenous 
resources.  The  use  of  imported  gas  for  power  generation  has  been  necessitated  by  the 
accelerated utilization of domestic gas reserves. 
 
2.  Transmission Sector 
46.  The total investment requirement for NTDC by 2016 is estimated at $3.9 billion. The 
urgent and immediate transmission system rehabilitation and augmentation plan for 2007–2011 
totals $915 million (32 transformers, 775 km of lines). Investments for 2012–2016 will mainly be 
to facilitate the evacuation from new generation plants as per the least-cost power generation 
plan. The transmission investment plan covers 62 transformers, 4,415 kilometers of lines, four 
SVCs,  and  20  new  grid  stations.  A  detailed  description  of  the  power  transmission  sector 
investment plan is provided in Appendix 3.

38  Appendix 3 
POWER TRANSMISSION SECTOR ROAD MAP AND INVESTMENT PLAN 
 
A.  Rationale  
1.  Pakistan’s power transmission system faces three major challenges: (i) the heavy power 
flow through the 500 kilovolt (kV) system, (ii) a shortage of supply capacity for the 220 kV 
system, and (iii) high transmission losses. Hydropower plants are located mainly in the northern 
parts of the country and the thermal plants are primarily located in the south. There is a heavy 
power flow from north to south during summer when hydropower generation is high, and a 
heavy flow from south to north in winter when hydropower generation is low. The mismatch 
between the location of demand and the source of supply is creating a considerable need for 
primary network investments. Current peak energy and capacity shortfalls are to some extent 
the consequence of shortages and bottlenecks in the national network. 
 
2.  The  Medium-Term  Development  Framework,  2005–2010  (MTDF)  spells  out  the 
Government’s energy sector strategy, including investments in power generation, transmission, 
and distribution. Based on the MTDF, the Government developed a long-term power generation 
plan. This identified the demand for increased generation capacity and addressed the size and 
timing of the commissioning of the new plants. The overall power transmission strategy is to 
ensure that the electricity from the new power generation plants is evacuated to the load 
centers.  
 
3.  According to Government estimates, electricity demand in Pakistan is forecasted to grow 
by at least 8% a year during 2005–2015. To meet this increasing demand, it is estimated that 
Pakistan will require an additional 2,000 megawatts (MWs) annually, which will need to be 
evacuated through the transmission system. Substantial investments will be need to strengthen 
the transmission system to (i) urgently address current shortfalls, (ii) evacuate power generated 
by additional power plants, and (iii) supply electricity to meet the growing demand. 
 
4.  High  growth  in  electricity  demand  in  Pakistan  is  clearly  putting  the  existing  power 
transmission infrastructure under severe stress and there is a clear need to invest in additional 
primary transmission facilities. This power transmission sector development road map is a 
comprehensive plan that specifies the details of system renovation and expansion based on the 
Government’s long-term power generation plan.  
 
B.  Objective 
5.  The objective of the road map is to show how the National Transmission and Despatch 
Company (NTDC) can deliver a reliable and high-quality power supply to the rising number of 
industrial,  commercial,  agricultural  and  domestic  customers.  It  is  consistent  with  the 
Government’s poverty reduction strategy and has the following intended outcomes: (i) a more 
efficient power system; (ii) high-quality power supply through a more reliable and stable system; 
(iii) greater  geographic  coverage;  and  (iv)  greater  availability  of  and  access  to  affordable 
electricity, by bringing hydroelectric and coal fired thermal energy to load centers. The Power 
Transmission Sector Road Map, 2007–2016, is in Table A3.1.

42  Appendix 4 
INVESTMENT PROGRAM SUPPORT COMPONENT 
 
1.  The  investment  program  support  component  under  tranche  1  of  the  multitranche 
financing facility (MFF) is for $10 million. It will focus on (i) subproject preparation, (ii) subproject 
implementation, and (iii) subproject monitoring activities. It will provide resources to ensure 
subproject preparatory activities linked to tranche 3 and subsequent tranches can be carried 
out. The component will also provide funds for the timely implementation of the approved 
subprojects, as well as providing knowledge transfer to the employees and management of 
National  Transmission  and  Despatch  Company  (NTDC)  through  the  preparation  and 
implementation processes. The component will ensure that the subprojects are implemented in 
accordance with the approved specifications and in particular that the environmental and social 
safeguard  aspects  are  implemented  in  accordance  with  the  approved  plans,  through  the 
establishment of a monitoring function. 
 
2.  NTDC’s  experience  in  all  technical  aspects  of  power  transmission  is  satisfactory. 
However,  training  in  modern  transmission  planning,  utility  management,  and  information 
communications and technology is needed. The investment program support component will 
strengthen  NTDC’s  (i)  planning,  (ii) design,  (iii)  project  management,  (iv)  operations,  and 
(iv) maintenance activities. Bilateral exchange programs will be developed with foreign power 
transmission companies to develop role models among current and potential managers.  
 
3.  The subproject preparatory activities under the investment program support component 
will help NTDC to prepare the subprojects under tranche 3 and later. It will also provide funding 
in preparation for power evacuation from the proposed imported-coal-fired power station in the 
Karachi area. The objective of the component is to establish the resources and structures within 
NTDC to enable it to carry out project preparatory, implementation, and monitoring activities. 
Preparation of the subprojects will include a feasibility study of the proposed 1,300-kilometer 
(km)  transmission  line  from  Karachi  to  Lahore,  based  on  the  proposed  imported-coal-fired 
power station in the Karachi area. NTDC asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to consider 
financing this subproject under the Investment Program.  ADB will review the feasibility report of 
the proposed project, after which it will indicate whether it is willing to finance it. ADB would be 
prepared to consider financing such a long and complex transmission line project outside the 
Investment Program. 
 
4.  In order to achieve the objectives of this component successfully, there will be three 
work streams. The first work stream, preparatory activities, will focus on: (i) transmission sector 
planning;  (ii)  individual  subproject  identification;  (iii)  subproject  assessments  (technical, 
financial,  economic,  environmental,  and  social);  (iv)  detailed  design;  and  (v)  procurement 
document preparation and bid evaluation.  
 
5.  The second work stream, implementation of the subprojects, will focus on: (i) program 
and  project  management;  (ii)  technical  operation  and  maintenance;  (iii)  contracting, 
procurement, and inventory management; (iv) accounting, financial and economic management, 
and financial reporting; (v) the management information system and (vi) the economics of cost 
recovery and tariff setting.  
 
6.  The third work stream, monitoring the subprojects, will focus on (i) establishment of a 
project  performance  monitoring  system,  including  permanent  and  contractual  staffing; 
(ii) periodic performance reviews of the subprojects and the overall Investment Program to 
evaluate  their  scope,  implementation  arrangements,  progress,  and  achievements;

Appendix 4       43     
(iii) environmental monitoring; (iv) benefit monitoring; and (v) social impact and resettlement 
monitoring. 
 
7.  The outline terms of reference (TORs) for each of the three work streams are provided in 
Supplementary Appendix F. It is envisioned that NTDC will engage several consulting teams 
and individual consultants for the same subcomponent, and the outline TORs will be similar for 
each consulting team.  NTDC will also be able to engage consultants to address subprojects 
that may not necessarily be financed or intended to be financed by ADB.

44  Appendix 5 
FINANCING PLAN 
 
1.  If the Government of Pakistan’s growth targets are to be met, it is projected that demand 
for  power  will  grow  by  10,000  megawatts  (MW)  by  2010.    Without  a  stable  and  reliable 
transmission system, any additional generated power will not be evacuated or delivered to 
customers. The total investment needs for the next 10 years are estimated to be $3.9 billion. 
The National Transmission and Despatch Company (NTDC) plans to fund 30% of this through 
self-generated funds and the rest through borrowing from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
and other financiers. The Government is actively looking for funding from the private sector and 
other agencies, but other financiers have not been confirmed. ADB’s proposed multitranche 
financing  facility  (MFF)  will  act  as  the  anchor  for  the  investment  plan.  Financing  of  the 
immediate and urgent subprojects planned for tranches 1 and 2 will provide additional revenues 
for NTDC to carry out the large investments for energy evacuation from independent power 
producers (IPPs) from tranche 3 onwards. The investment program support component, funded 
from  ADB’s  Asian  Development  Fund  (ADF)  resources,  will  assist  NTDC  to  structure  the 
subprojects so they can attract investment from commercial sources.

million) are included.  The other eight subprojects will range in cost from $43 million to $228 
million. NTDC will depend on commercial and other financiers for 66% of the financing for these 
subprojects. The 33% self-financing portion will be supported by the revenues generated from 
projects in tranches 1 and 2. The investment program support component will be crucial for 
making these subprojects attractive to commercial lenders and investors. The feasibility study 
and marketing to attract investors to these large projects will take place at the same time as 
efforts to attract investors to the generation projects. Consultants under the investment program 
support component will work closely with the Private Power Investment Board.

54  Appendix 9 
FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT OF THE POWER TRANSMISSION SECTOR 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Financial  management  of  National  Transmission  Despatch  Company  (NTDC)  was 
reviewed and found to be adequate.  NTDC has the ability to undertake and fulfill fiduciary 
requirements  for  the  proposed  Investment  Program.  Financial  management  assessment 
questionnaires  and  field  interviews  were  used  to  review  the  present  standing  of  financial 
management. Due consideration has been taken into account of the fact that NTDC is in 
transition from being a part of Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) to a fully 
independent corporate entity. Progress on strengthening corporate governance and financial 
management is under way. Available public financial management assessment diagnostic tools, 
such as the World Bank’s comprehensive country financial accountability assessment1 and 
public expenditure review2, and ADB assistance programs3 were reviewed to assess NTDC’s 
financial system.   
 
1.  Corporate Structure 
2.  The NTDC is a public limited company incorporated in Pakistan in November 1998 and 
commenced  commercial  operations  on  March  1999.  The  NTDC  was  granted  transmission 
license TL/01/2002 on 31 December 2002 by NEPRA to engage as the exclusive transmission 
company for a term of 30 years, pursuant to section 17 of the Electric Power Act of 1997. This 
30  years  license  calls  for  NTDC  to  undertake  three  specific  functions:  (i)  transmission 
operations of the high voltage lines (220 kV and above), (ii) the dispatch of all power generation 
linked to the national grid, and (iii) the single purchaser/seller of power.  
 
3.  As the sole transmission company in Pakistan, NTDC is to (i) maintain and upgrade the 
current system, (ii) plan, design, and implement system expansions, and (iii) operate the system 
dispatch generation according to system requirements and transmission license conditions, for 
smooth  transmission  of  electricity  from  generation  companies  to  distribution  companies 
countrywide. The company took over properties, rights, assets obligations and liabilities of 220 
kV and 500 kV grid stations and transmission lines/ network owned by WAPDA under the 
Business Transfer Agreement of 1 March 1999.  
 
4.  The Government has proposed that the single buyer function licensed to NTDC be 
handled by an independent agency. Procedures are on–going for separation of this function and 
financial accounts from NTDC. A new license will have to be issued to NTDC and the Central 
Power Purchasing Agency (CPPA). Tariff determinations will have to be made for CPPA and 
agreements with generation companies and independent power producers have been revised. 
As an interim measure, CPPA will be managed separately within NTDC. A part of WAPDA 
Private Power Organization will be restructured to take on the task of CPPA.  
 
B.  Financial Management Issues and Mitigating Measures 
5.  The financial sustainability of the power transmission sector is dependent on timely and 
accurate (i) submission of tariff applications by NTDC, (ii) execution of the tariff determination by

2 Pakistan Public Expenditure Management, Strategic Issues and Reform Agenda, World Bank, January 2004
