Appendix 9       55     
National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA), (iii) notification of the tariff determination 
by the Government, and (iv) collection of payments from distribution companies to NTDC for 
transmission charges. As for corporate issues, NTDC has (v) financial and (vi) management 
independence issues that need to be remedied. 
 
1.  Tariff Issue (i), (ii) and (iii) 
 
6.  In  the  tariff  determination,  revenue  requirement  cover  general  establishment  and 
administrative expenses, insurance, repair & maintenance (1% gross fixed assets in operation), 
NEPRA license fee (adjusted for inflation), depreciation (3.5% of average gross fixed assets), 
debt servicing (11.71% weighted average cost of debt) and, corporate income taxe (35%) and 
return on equity self-financing for its capacity expansion program (12.75%) less other income.  
The latest tariff determination was in January 2006 for 2005-2006.  The application was made 
by NTDC on 30 May 2005.  Stakeholders were notified of the salient features in a newspaper 
advertisement on 11 June 2005. In response to the interventions NEPRA decided to hold a 
hearing  on  22  August  and  issues  raised  by  the  stakeholders  were  addressed  by  NTDC. 
Determination was notified on 6 January 2006.   This tariff will remain effective until the next 
application by NTDC, determination by NEPRA and notification by government.   Two types of 
tariff are determined for transmission the fixed and variable use of systems charge.   
 
7.  Although  NEPRA’s  determination  procedures  took  6  months,  considering  the  due 
process involved this is not excessive.  The quality of the past submissions by NTDC seems 
adequate  upon  inspection  and  has  withstood  the  determination  process.  NTDC  is  taking 
measures to improve the timeliness of tariff revision petitions to NEPRA however the next 
revision is not necessary until 2008. The level of tariff determined stands to logic and is at a cost 
recovery level with allowance for the investment.   
 
2.  Financial independence (iv) and (v)  
 
8.  The  unbundling  of  the  power  sector  has  been  on-going  since  1999.  To  achieve 
efficiencies  and  transparency  that  were  intended  through  unbundling,  financial  as  well  as 
management  independence  is  necessary.  NTDC  continues  to  be  financially  dependent  on 
WAPDA, NTDC currently has satisfactory accounting capacities and established accredited 
external audit processes in accordance with international audit standards. In addition, NTDC is 
developing  sufficient  in  house  functions  and  systems  to  handle  payments,  billings,  and 
collections. Accordingly, these functions can safely be transferred from WAPDA to NTDC.       
 
3.  Management Independence (vi) 
 
9.  As the transition period is concluding and NTDC has built capacity for independence 
from WAPDA, the corporate governance structure of its Board should be in accordance with 
best international practices. Currently, the Board consists of a Chairman, three members from 
the private sector, and three officials. The Board represents the interest of the sole owner, the 
Government.  The nomination of the board members is made by Chairman Pakistan Electric 
Power Company (PEPCO) in accordance with a presidential directive.   The Chairman of NTDC 
and another Director hold concurrent seats in WAPDA, PEPCO and NTDC.  The unbundling 
process has come to a stage where the same individual holding multiple board of directors’ 
positions may not be the most efficient way of promoting Government’s power sector policy. 
With the independence of NTDC, the representatives who hold seats in WAPDA or any other 
company that holds generation assets has conflict of interest.  Persons with such conflict of 
interest may find it difficult to duly exercise their fiduciary duties and their oversight role.

4.  Other issues 
 
10.  The  current  on-lending  rate  is  17%  pursuant  to  a  government  circular  of  1996 
concerning on-lending to autonomous state owned entities.  This rate is currently above the rate 
paid by NTDC for its commercial borrowing, around 12%.  Instead of a fixed rate, consideration 
should be given to benchmark the rates to the borrowing cost of the Government with premium 
charged  for  foreign  exchange  and  credit  risk  of  NTDC  (autonomous  government  entity). 
However, even with this rate, the projects under Tranche 1 are financially viable.  
 
11.  NTDC  inherited  a  manual  accounting  system  from  WAPDA  and  which  is  being 
computerized at present. The Head Office has been computerized and the branches will be 
computerized by the end of 2006.  The speed of computerization and training has been in line 
with the plan thus far.  Expectation is for the progress to be consistent with the current pace.  
 
12.  The  internal  audit  function  currently  report  to  the  Chief  Executive  Officer  and  the 
procedures are based on those which they have inherited from WAPDA.  The Audit Committee 
which reports to the board was established last year and is chaired by an outside auditor with 
the  NTDC  Audit  Manager  as  the  Secretary.    Discussions  have  been  taking  place  in  this 
committee to establish NTDC’s own audit procedures and policies as an independent entity.   
 
C.  Financial Performance 
13.  The transmission business of NTDC (excluding CPPA) has been financially sound in the 
last 3 years.   Revenue from the transmission tariff was separated from CPPA only in 2005 and 
it is only during this year that the affect of CPPA on NTDC is visible. The tariff adjustment has 
allowed financing for operation, maintenance as well as a basis for their investment plan.

E.  Conclusion 
18.  The financial management of NTDC is adequate to carry out the fiduciary duties of the 
proposed Investment Program. In terms of financial strength, for the counter party funds, NTDC 
remains profitable up to 2015, even under a very conservative assumption that the annual 
increase in the UoSC from 2008 is only by 7.3%. Return on equity is 10% in 2010 and 6% in 
2015. More importantly NTDC produces adequate cashflow to maintain its operations and meet 
its debt service obligations. The debt service coverage ratio (DSRC) stands above 1.2 times 
from 2010 and the self financing ratio, is very satisfactory from 2010 onwards.  
 
19.  In terms of management, measures are being taken to strengthen the independence and 
transparency of the system.  These steps seem adequate and appropriate considering the 
maturity of NTDC in the unbundling process. The Investment Program Support Component of 
the Program will give additional assistance to hasten the process.

SUMMARY OF ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The proposed investment projects to be funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
are  part  of  Pakistan’s  integrated  generation  and  transmission  expansion  program,  and  an 
integral component of the transmission system development plan prepared by the National 
Transmission  and  Despatch  Company  (NTDC)  using  least-cost  planning  principles.  The 
economic analysis is based on a time-slice approach to the transmission system development 
plan, since individual subprojects are not stand-alone investments and in some instances would 
not yield all their benefits if they were considered in isolation. The economic internal rate of 
return compares the annual streams of economic capital and operating costs against benefits 
based on willingness to pay. All costs, benefits, and revenues are expressed in 2006 constant 
prices. The analysis period includes the construction period and 30 years of operation. Details 
of  the  assumptions  and  calculations  used  for  the  economic  analysis  are  presented  in 
Supplementary Appendix E. The economic analysis confirms that the Investment Program will 
ease chronic supply shortages in the country and help meet projected growth in demand for 
electric power. Demand forecasts and cost–benefit projections were prepared and analyzed and 
they indicated that the Investment Program is economically viable. 
 
B.  Demand Analysis 
2.  The nationwide power demand is projected to grow at 7.9% during 2006–2010 and to 
increase from 15,500 megawatts (MW) in FY 2006 to 21,500 MW in FY 200 (Table A10.1). To 
cope with the growth in electricity demand, it is estimated that Pakistan would require about 
2,000 additional MW newly installed capacity to be added annually. The additional generated 
power increase would need to be evacuated through the transmission system and brought to 
the consumers through the distribution systems.

C.  Economic Analysis Calculations 
1.  Least-Cost Review  
7.  In order to establish that the project provides the least-cost option (or part of the cost-
minimizing expansion plan), various load flow scenarios were undertaken. The transmission 
investments were confirmed to be an integral part of the least-cost power sector development 
program for Pakistan. 
 
2.  Cost–Benefit Analysis 
8.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) calculation was based on incremental cost 
and benefit streams associated with each tranche of investment. Economic performance was 
evaluated by comparing with- and without-project scenarios. Incremental consumption occurs 
because of the extended availability of lower-cost grid-sourced electricity. Economic benefits 
accrue to consumers and the economy as a result of the Investment Program.  
 
9.  The main benefits stem from (i) removing existing bottlenecks by facilitating efficient 
evacuation of power from existing power stations, (ii) improving efficiency reliability and system 
security, (iii) evacuating power from additional power stations, and (iv) reducing losses. The

62  Appendix 10 
physical output—rehabilitated, augmented, and expanded transmission infrastructure—will add 
to existing supply (incremental benefit) and will substitute for alternative forms of energy supply. 
The  incremental  benefits  were  valued  for  each  category  of  customer,  using  customers’ 
willingness to pay for electricity. 
 
3.  Calculation of Willingness to Pay 
10.  The value of each unit of electricity to customers was estimated by comparing current 
prices against the price of alternative sources of electricity. Particular consumer classes were 
assumed to be willing to pay the difference between the present cost for an alternative source of 
electricity and the amount charged for incremental grid-supplied units. This was used as the 
basis for the willingness to pay calculation. The analysis identified four classes of electricity 
consumer: agricultural, residential, commercial, and industrial. The focus is on the main energy 
use (and the alternative source), rather than on the full range of appliances used by the 
customer category to calculate the real value for lost load. Table A10.4 shows the willingness to 
pay and price of alternative energy for each consumer category.

4.  Results 
11.  The  economic  cost–benefit  analysis  results  in  an  EIRR  of  24%  for  the  Investment 
Program. The net benefits of the Investment Program were estimated to be $3.7 billion. The 
sensitivity analyses show that the Investment Program remains justified even if various risks 
materialize. Tranches 3 and 4 are sensitive to reductions in demand, but this is considered a 
relatively small risk given Pakistan’s long history of unmet demand.

12.  The economic feasibility of the proposed subprojects in tranche 1 has been tested by 
establishing the need for the subprojects, and establishing that they represent the least-cost 
means of achieving their objectives. The analysis results in an EIRR of 37%, justifying the 
viability of tranche 1 investment. Pakistan is a net importer of energy; there are currently peak 
energy and capacity shortfalls; and growth in demand is forecast to continue. The subprojects 
aim to reduce system losses, increase system reliability, and improve quality of supply, thereby 
reducing the need for consumers to resort to costly self or captive power generation. The 
subprojects will allow new consumers to be connected to the system. The summary of the

64  Appendix 11 
SUMMARY SOCIAL SAFEGUARDS 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The Government of Pakistan has requested $800 million from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to undertake the Power Transmission Enhancement Investment Program (the 
Investment Program). The Investment Program, to be financed by a multitranche financing 
facility (MFF), will target Punjab, Islamabad and North-West Frontier Province (NWFP) with, the 
National Transmission and Dispatch Company (NTDC) as the Executing Agency. The Program 
will be divided into tranches, each covering subprojects for the construction or improvement of 
transmission lines and grid stations. New transmission line or station construction will have land 
acquisition and resettlement (LAR) impacts. This appraisal of social safeguards includes an 
appraisal of tranche 1, two subprojects of which have LAR: the Mardan–Line Bay extension and 
transmission line, and the new Bandala station and transmission line. Subprojects implemented 
in NWFP may have impacts on indigenous peoples (IP).   
  
B.  General Procedures 
 
2.  LAR will follow Pakistan law and ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement (1995), and 
Operations  Manual  F2  on  involuntary  resettlement  (2003).  The  Investment  Program,  each 
tranche appraisal, and the approval and implementation of each subproject with LAR or IP 
issues will require the following documents: 
(i)  a land acquisition and resettlement framework (LARF) and an IP development 
framework (IPDF) for the whole Investment Program to be reviewed, updated, 
and re-approved by ADB annually and before the preparation of each tranche; 
(ii)  an initial poverty and social assessment (IPSA) indicating whether LAR or IP 
impacts are expected, and if so their type and magnitude for each tranche; 
(iii)  a land acquisition and resettlement plan (LARP) with detailed design and impact 
figures and compensation budgets and schedules for each project with LAR;1 
and  
(iv)  an IP development plan (IPDP) or appropriate IP action for all projects affecting IPs.   
3.  The appraisal of the Investment Program and of each tranche and the approval and 
implementation  of  each  subproject  under  a  tranche  will  follow  the  following  LAR-related 
conditions: 
(i)  Investment Program and tranche 1. Preparation of the LARF and IPDF for the 
Investment Program, and LARPs and IPDPs for tranche 1 subprojects with LAR 
or IP impacts.  
(ii)  Other tranches. LARF and IPDF review and update and preparation of LARP 
and IPDP for all subrojects with LAR or IP impacts. 
(iii)  Start of subproject civil works. LARP and IPDP implementation. 
 
4.  To comply with these conditions, the NTDP has prepared a LARF and an IPDF for the 
whole MFF and a LARP for the Mardan and Bandala subprojects under tranche 1.  
                                                 
1 As per ADB. 2003. Operations Manual. Section F2: Involuntary Resettlement. Manila, the length of a resettlement 
plan depends on the severity of the impacts. If impacts are severe (> 200 AP resettled or with >10% income 
losses), a project is classified as “A” and a full resettlement plan is required. If impacts are not severe (<200 AP 
resettled or with <10% income losses), a project is classified as “B” and only a short resettlement plan is required.

Appendix 11     65     
C.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement Framework  
5.  The LARF is based on the following principles: (i) LAR will be avoided, or minimized if it 
cannot be avoided, (ii) compensation will ensure the maintenance of the APs’ pre-project living 
standards, (iii) APs will be fully informed and consulted on compensation options, (iv) AP socio-
cultural institutions will be supported and used, (v) LAR provisions will apply equally to women 
and  men,  (vi)  lack  of  formal  title  will  not  be  a  bar  to  compensation  and  rehabilitation, 
(vii) particular attention will be paid to households headed by women and to vulnerable groups, 
(viii) LAR will be conceived and executed as an integral part of the project and LAR budgets will 
be included in project costs, and (ix) compensation will be fully provided prior to ground leveling 
and demolition. The LARF also covers all issues relevant to LAR and contains the following 
eligibility and entitlement provisions.

6.  Institutional Responsibilities. NTDC has overall responsibility for LAR preparation, 
implementation, and financing and will exercise its functions through two project management 
units  (PMUs),  responsible  for  general  project  execution  in  their  areas,  and  project 
implementation units (PIUs), responsible for project-level activities. At the PMUs, LAR tasks will 
be handled by a land acquisition and resettlement unit (LARU). The LARU will be aided by a 
social safeguard team under the project preparation and supervision consultants and by NGOs 
or  impact  assessment  or  valuation  teams  hired  for  onsite  impact  surveys  or  monitoring 
assistance. PMUs will coordinate with local governments, which have jurisdiction over land 
administration and valuation. At the provincial level these tasks rest with the Board of Revenue 
while at district level they rest with the district collector office (DCO) and the land acquisition 
collector (LAC). Agents such as the Patwari (land records keeper) will identify and verify titles. 
Compensation for assets other than land or income rehabilitation is the responsibility of the 
relevant district department. To ensure effective coordination between the Executing Agency, 
local governments, and other agencies, NTDC will establish an LAR steering committee at the 
provincial level. An LAR coordination committee (LCC), including the elected representatives of 
the APs, will be established by NTDC in each project district. Clearance of category B LARPs 
and IPDPs will be done by a social development specialist at the Resident Mission. Category A 
projects will be cleared at ADB headquarters.  
  
7.  Disclosure/Public Consultation. LARP tasks will need intense AP consultation. The 
LARF and relevant LARPs were disclosed on the ADB website in English. The LARF and 
LARPs in local languages will be disclosed in the APs’ communities. 
 
8.  Grievance Procedures. APs may first lodge a complaint with the LAC. If settlement is 
not reached within 30 days, the complaint may be lodged with the PMU. If the grievance is not 
settled within another 30 days, the APs can seek redress at the appropriate court. The LCC, 
which includes senior members of the APs communities and their elected representatives will 
assist the APs in these cases and will help them to communicate with NTDC.   
 
9.   Monitoring and Evaluation. PMUs will internally monitor and report to the EA on LAR 
implementation. The EA will report to ADB quarterly. External monitoring will be assigned to an 
independent agency by the EA and external monitoring reports will be submitted to ADB once a 
year. At the end of project implementation the independent monitoring agency will carry out a 
general evaluation of LAR implementation. 
 
10.  Finances and Schedules. The LARF mandates that each LARP will detail LAR budgets 
and provide clear schedules linking LAR tasks with the initiation of civil works.

Appendix 11     67     
D.  Specific Land Acquisition and Resettlement Plans  
 
11.  Two subprojects under tranche 1, Mardan station and transmission line and Bandala 
station and transmission line will involve LAR. For both subprojects, a LARP in line with ADB’s 
policy and LARF requirements has been prepared, based on a detailed design.  
 
12.  The Mardan subproject will affect 1.34 ha of agricultural land and 73.54 ha of crops. 
There are 148 affected families (1,415 individuals). No AP will be resettled as no residential or 
commercial land or house or structure is affected. LAR costs are estimated to be $640,000.  
 
13.  The Bandala subproject will affect about 0.3 ha of agricultural land, 132 trees and 12 ha 
of crops (sugar, maize/wheat, rice). There are 24 affected families (174 individuals). No AP will 
be  resettled  as  no  house  or  residential  or  commercial  plot  is  affected.  LAR  budgets  are 
estimated to be $96,000.  
 
E.  Indigenous Peoples Issues    
 
14.  IP will be affected only by projects in NWFP’s tribal areas. As these projects are yet to 
be identified, no IPDP has been prepared so far. However, in accordance with ADB’s IP policy 
provisions, NTDC has drafted an IPDF detailing: (i) IP-related project processing conditions; 
(ii) IPDP preparation and implementation requirements; (iii) IP definition in Pakistan; (iv) results 
of a general social assessment; (v) an IP strategy for the Investment Program and a definition of 
the type of IP action needed; (vi) IPDP participation instruments; and (vii) general processing 
and implementation issues. 
 
15.  Based on the IPDF provisions and the social assessment results it is assumed that the 
Pakistan  definition  of  “tribal  peoples”  will  correspond  to  ADB’s  definition  of  IP.  The  IPSA 
prepared for each tranche will include an indigenous peoples identification assessment (IPIA) 
providing (i) general information on projects likely to affect IPs, the magnitude of the anticipated 
impact, and the number and type of IPDPs to be prepared, and (ii) an outline of IP groups likely 
to be affected, with an overview of their demography, social organization, livelihood and land 
tenure features, relations with government and other groups, adaptation to outside society and 
culture, and forms of local governance. 
 
16.  The IPDF also indicates the two types of IP action that will be needed, based on the 
magnitude of the impact and the situation.  
(i)  If impacts affecting IPs are limited to LAR and have no broad community or 
systemic effect requiring the rehabilitation of an entire productive system, specific 
IP actions to mitigate the impacts will be included in the LARP.  
 
(ii)  If the impacts affecting IPs go beyond standard LAR effects and cause broad 
disruption  with  systemic  sociocultural  dimensions  and  wide  economic  and 
community  effects,  a  stand-alone  IPDP  (including  a  detailed  action  plan, 
schedules and budgets) will be prepared. The stand-alone IPDP will not only 
cover LAR issues, but will provide a detailed action plan based on direct IP 
participation  in  the  socioeconomic  rehabilitation  of  the  affected  communities, 
including the provision of community development packages. 
 
17.  Institutional responsibilities. Based on the IPDF, NTDC will have overall responsibility 
for actions related to IPs, including IPDP preparation, implementation, financing and monitoring

68  Appendix 11 
through the two PMUs and the PIUs. The PMUs will be assisted by the social safeguards team 
under the project preparation and supervision consultants and by NGOs in project areas. The 
PMUs will coordinate with local government authorities in tribal areas and with IPs’ communal 
organizations. They will carry out all activities related to IPs in a way that is consistent with the 
administrative and political process prevalent in tribal areas. In particular, the PMUs will carry 
out their tasks in association with the political agent and the district coordinator offices. Through 
them, it will make workable arrangements with the tribal leaders concerned (maliks, sardars or 
khans). The tribal leaders will consult their tribal councils (jirgas) and/or communities to make 
the final decisions and take necessary actions in line with the Project’s requirements. To ensure 
coordination with the governments of the tribal territories, the political agents will be members of 
the LAR steering committee in NWFP and Baluchistan and of the LAR coordination committees 
at district level. ADB  clearance of category  B LARP and IPDPs will be done by a social 
development specialist the Resident Mission. Category A projects (with stand-alone IPDPs) will 
be cleared at ADB Headquarters.  
  
18.  Complaints and Grievances. Complaints from affected IPs may be addressed to the 
political agent’s office via tribal leaders and councils (maliks, sardars, or khans, and/or jirga 
councils). If convinced that the IPs have a case, the political agent will then call on the PMU or 
NTDC headquarters to discuss, negotiate, and resolve the complaint. If NTDC, the political 
agent,  and  the  tribal  leaders  cannot  find  mutually  agreeable  solutions  to  a  grievance  the 
relevant subproject may not be implemented.  
 
19.  Public Consultation and Disclosure. IP tasks will be planned and executed on the 
basis of intense consultation with the affected communities. As an appraisal condition for future 
tranches, the IPDF and relevant IPDPs in English will be disclosed on the ADB website. The 
IPDF and IPDPs in local languages will be disclosed in the APs’ communities.   
 
20.  Monitoring and Evaluation. PMUs  will  monitor  and  report  to  the  EA  on  IPDP 
implementation. The EA will report to ADB quarterly. External monitoring will be assigned to an 
independent agency by the EA and external monitoring reports will be submitted to ADB once a 
year. At the end of project implementation the independent monitoring agency will carry out a 
general evaluation of IPDP implementation. 
 
21.  Finances and Schedules. The IPDF mandates that each stand-alone IPDP will detail 
budgets and provide clear schedules linking LAR tasks with the initiation of civil works.

Appendix 12       69     
SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY  
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis  
Is the sector identified as a national    Yes  Is the sector identified as a national priority in  N/A  
priority in country poverty analysis?     country poverty partnership agreement?  
    No 
Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan:  
Major interventions in the energy sector are designed to achieve economic progress through infrastructure 
development. Both physical investment support and sector reform are necessary so that the benefits from economic 
growth will accrue to the poor.  
 
By expanding transmission capacity, the proposed Investment Program is expected to result in quality and reliable 
delivery of services to consumers, particularly benefiting commercial, residential, and agricultural customers in the 
region.  
 
Poor and vulnerable consumers, including social utilities such as hospitals and schools, are often the hardest hit by 
inadequate power supply, load shedding, and poor power quality. They will benefit directly from the subprojects. Direct 
positive economic and social benefits will result from the Investment Program.  
 
A positive, direct impact on local labor is expected during implementation and an indirect impact will be due to the 
increased income-earning opportunities generated by increased access to electricity and job opportunities during 
construction. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                       Proposed Classification: General intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
Project preparatory technical assistance consultants have prepared a social impact assessment and a poverty impact 
assessment. A socioeconomic survey was undertaken to provide a basis for the assessments.  
 
Grid-sourced power will have productive use, as it will substitute for wood, kerosene, and candles, usually at lower 
costs. After the first 3 years of operations, total benefits will be in the range of $200,000–$250,000 added value 
through production or services. Approximately 250 persons will generate additional income for tranche 1 subprojects. 
 
Most poor people in Pakistan are wage labourers or are self-employed. Over 40% of them live close to the poverty line; 
this indicates that shocks, such as illness, death or drought, have the potential to drive large numbers into poverty. 
Most are landless and less likely to have access to a health clinic or to send their children to school than those with 
higher incomes. A disruption of their daily routine makes them more vulnerable than other groups as they do not have 
the resources to insure against such disruptions. 
 
The Investment Program is expected to create new full-time employment opportunities in civil works. Improved power 
supplies will induce light industrial and commercial activity, creating employment and improving the productivity and 
quality of outputs in manufacturing and agriculture sectors.   
 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
Stakeholder analysis has been undertaken. All stakeholders have been actively involved, in order to reduce the 
likelihood of grievances and to ensure that benefits are distributed fairly. In addition, for the selection of unskilled labor 
in the project area, the contractors will consult with local township labor officials, local village leaders and jirgas and will 
also ensure that labor is hired on a nondiscriminatory basis.   
 
 
D.  Gender and Development   
Strategy to maximize impacts on women:  
 
The poor and women were included in participatory activities.  
 
Has an output been prepared?      Yes      No
